Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died after a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, was found guilty of causing death by careless driving. He pleaded guilty at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. Werner's family, who were staying in a cottage near Bala, saw no value in him being sent to jail as they accepted it was a momentary lapse. Werner was remorseful but had no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British man from Southall, west London, is accused of being one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from the Syria conflict. He, under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group of British fighters affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was known for his online presence, posting videos and pictures of his personal jihad in Syria. He was involved in fundraising, propaganda, and appeals for donations. However, he faked his own death and tried to slip back into the UK unnoticed, leading to his arrest and prosecution at the Old Bailey. Khawaja is currently facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in the conflict.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish 8th in the table. Barnsley has signed him as their third player for the upcoming League One play-off final at Wembley. The caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and defensive skills, stating that he will fit well with the team's playing style. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season.

Volunteers are clearing bottles from Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, believed to be from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End. The bottles, sealed but some leaking, pose a risk to wildlife. Other coves are also affected, causing concern for marine life. The National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation, with the bottles being cleared away by the trust. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from any more washed-up bottles.

A car crash happened on the A9 near Berriedale, Caithness, at 14:00, injuring several people. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 to Melvich. Police are investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Wanderers, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and securing promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite's contribution was particularly significant towards the end of the campaign. He has since signed a new contract with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The election issue of foreign policy and the role of UK's defence forces at home and abroad includes defence spending and the UK's military capabilities. The Conservative and Labour parties have made significant cuts to their armed forces, reducing the size of the regular Army, the Royal Navy's fleet, and the RAF's front-line fast jet squadrons. Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with additional fees totaling £106.8m, including a £34m payment to Neymar's parents. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated. A judge in Spain has ruled to continue investigations into the transfer. Neymar has scored 15 goals in total for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, a 66-year-old man who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family and Age UK have called for retired drivers to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations. Newman's car was heading north on the southbound carriageway when it collided with a van Luciw was traveling in. Luciw's colleague, Andy Harrington, was also in the van and survived with serious injuries. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The passage discusses the safety concerns of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in Scotland. Two original review group members resigned due to a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report, which concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and informed choices, and that reporting of adverse events be mandatory. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the power to ban the procedures, as that lies with the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, who had suffered complications from the surgery, resigned from the review group earlier this year. Muir, a 23-year-old, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record for 5000 meters by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan, who had raised concerns about the criteria for record-breaking attempts, acknowledged Muir's achievement. She had earlier expressed doubts about whether Muir's race met the requirements, as it was a mixed 3K race where only Muir finished the 5K. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's ability and potential to win world medals, noting that her time was similar to McColgan's own record-breaking race 25 years ago. Muir had previously broken her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

In the 2016 Rio Olympics equestrian event, Jung won the gold medal aboard Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who contracted an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and America's Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, 47, competed despite being placed in an induced coma 10 months prior, but his medal bid was ruined by a poor cross-country performance. He finished 12th after leading after dressage but incurring time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished 9th on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

30-year-old British tennis player Andy Murray won his fourth round match at Wimbledon against Italian 29th seed Fognini. Murray won 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to seal the victory. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray was not at his best but managed to get through the match. The match was tense and Murray avoided a long, drawn-out contest in the third set. Fognini was on the defensive in the fourth set and Murray showed all his fighting qualities to save set points. Murray will have a day's break before his next match.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death. Despite police finding several people still at the bar when they arrived, alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST, as shown by till receipts. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and her partner James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern about their record and fined O'Neill £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge also mentioned that O'Neill had an appalling record and that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched their manifesto, 'Real Partnership', which includes plans to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and ensure no group is worse off due to Brexit. Nesbitt emphasized that the election is a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP and Sinn Féin's time in Stormont. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, announced that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales in implementing automatic pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences. This includes posthumous pardons for those who have passed away and the option for living men to apply for a pardon. The law, known as 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing and aims to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, who have historically faced different treatment compared to their counterparts in England and Wales. The minister has secured executive agreement to introduce a legislative consent motion for the pardon of convictions related to abolished sexual offences, with the aim of addressing past wrongs and providing earlier resolution than an assembly bill. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

23-year-old Scottish runner Laura Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m event, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12. This result improved upon Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60. Muir also holds the Scottish records for the 1500m and mile events. She is currently preparing for the British trials in Birmingham on June 24-26 to secure an Olympics spot for Great Britain in Rio. Muir recently completed her fourth year of veterinary studies and started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, last week. She will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm.

The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a Russian spy who died in London in 2006 after consuming tea laced with a radioactive substance, polonium-210. Horwell believes the Russian state was involved in Litvinenko's murder, with reasons including harm and death, and that the only credible explanation is state involvement. However, he clarified that this does not imply Russian President Vladimir Putin's involvement or the order of the murder. Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticisms of the Russian government, including allegations of murder and corruption, could have been seen as treachery. The suspects left a trail of polonium and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Despite attempts to extradite the suspects, they remain in Russia, and the inquiry is adjourn

Steve Smith, at 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, following Michael Clarke's retirement. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests last summer. He has played in 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary issues. Warner has matured and developed into a senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting on 20 August.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights, stating that he is "passionate" about them and will prioritize equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people. He previously voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, specifically the spousal veto issue, but now supports equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

In 2015, Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in the UK, leading to the loss of 450 jobs. However, Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical firm, has since taken over the plant to produce its pharmaceuticals. Accord aims to fill many of the jobs with former Sanofi staff and is confident the investment will have a positive impact on the local economy. The move is welcomed by Newcastle City Council, which sees it as a boost to the local science and healthcare sector and a strengthening of the region's reputation. Accord Healthcare produces over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance, and heads of the chief executive's office (Ciaran Monaghan) and human resources and customer services (Ewan Sutherland), are all leaving the local authority. Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. The SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, criticized the departures as indicative of the council's struggle to retain senior staff and expects more departures in the future. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the departing staff for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, has decided to stop road racing on Hondas this year after crashing at the TT and facing mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement but later clarified that he's not giving up on racing or road racing. However, he won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's lack of competitiveness, as decided by the team after further testing at Cadwell. Martin expressed his desire to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorship posts in the recent Nigerian elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has been in power since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari is set to be inaugurated on 29 May, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll. The PDP's decline was further reinforced by the election results for governors and state assemblies, as they lost in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and in Adamawa, one of the states badly hit by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC also failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production and starve the federal government of oil revenue. The passage discusses allegations made by environmental lobby group Mighty against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. The claims include turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The passage mentions that a restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law was implemented, permitting dogs to dine outdoors. The law change allowed for this unusual service, as shown in a clip.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube following Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version. The ban, imposed in 2012 due to a controversial US-made film, was lifted after Google agreed to a deal with the Pakistan government. Google will now directly receive requests from the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to block offending material. However, Google will not automatically grant government requests for content removal, and such requests will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban was criticized for its potential impact on freedom of speech and expression in Pakistan.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, a member of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and his eligibility to participate in the presidential election to replace Sepp Blatter. Scala, who is Swiss-Italian, excused himself from the 2015 elections due to a conflict of interest as he shared nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were fatally injured at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area when a flashover explosion occurred, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon, and forensic inquiries, including a forensic search at the company and obtaining witness statements, are ongoing. The Health and Safety Executive will also be gathering evidence.

Tunisia was facing expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against CAF, but was allowed to participate after apologizing. Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but the ban was overturned after reducing a fine from $1m to $50,000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Tunisia had a dispute with CAF over a controversial penalty in the 2015 quarter-finals, leading to a demand for an apology by CAF or disqualification. Tunisia and CAF reconciled, and Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

In the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1 against Manchester City. The match was marred by a mass brawl, with City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho receiving four-match and three-match bans respectively for violent conduct. Aguero, 28, was sent off for a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, while Fernandinho was involved in the scuffle that followed. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the incident. Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a cancer screening program in the Rhondda Cynon Taf area of Wales. The program aims to identify people with cancer symptoms early through regular screening. The program has been successful in detecting cancer at an early stage, with 40% of those screened in the Nantgarw area having been diagnosed with cancer. However, some people may not have any symptoms and still need to be screened. The program is expected to continue in the future, with the aim of identifying cancer at an even earlier stage. The program has been praised for its effectiveness in detecting cancer early, which can improve treatment outcomes and survival rates. The program is part of a wider effort to improve cancer care in Wales.

England won the match against Pakistan with a significant margin at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England's Joe Root scored 254 in the first innings and 71 in the second, while also taking four catches and a wicket. Root's performance was praised for its control and discipline. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50. The series is expected to be tight, with Pakistan playing a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test.

Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has named Rob Howley as an interim coach for the New Zealand tour. Forwards coach Steve McBryde will lead the team as head coach for the third time, having previously led Wales tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his excitement and honor to represent his country and lead the team overseas. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde, and they hope to confirm the full management team by next week. Welsh coaches' involvement in the Lions' tour is expected to benefit the national team and provide a valuable opportunity for their development.

The passage is about a football match between Southampton and Hull City. The match ended with Hull City winning 2-1, which was their first win since August 20. The match was played in front of a sparse crowd due to Hull's poor form and the international break. The win ended Southampton's six-game losing streak and they remain in the bottom three.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, at around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist, who is locally resident, was not injured in the crash. The tractor driver was unharmed. The road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction for investigation. Lincolnshire Police is appealing for witnesses to come forward.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, citing the need to end the crisis before early elections in June. However, this decision was criticized by the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of covert recordings allegedly showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and a murder cover-up. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev accused the government of wiretapping 20,000 people, including politicians, journalists, and religious leaders, and of corruption at the highest levels. The government denied these accusations, and the crisis has put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. The club, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is struggling to maintain their position and has lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and emphasizes the importance of the club's history and the impact of the 'Swansea Way'. The Daggers, Dagenham & Redbridge, reached League One in 2010 and 2007 respectively. Dagenham reached the Football League for the first time in 2007 but are now returning to the National League under manager John Still. Dagenham has the worst goal difference in League Two and has conceded 20 more goals this season than last term. John Still, who returned for his third spell at Dagenham in December, is committed to helping the club gain promotion from the National League next season. Dagenham's loss leaves Leyton Orient two points adrift of the play-off spots, four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role. Orient interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games to secure play-off spots.

36-year-old former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won multiple trophies with the club, left for MLS side LA Galaxy in 2015. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but decided it was too soon. He is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

Morton won the match 3-1 against Alloa Athletic. McManus scored twice, with Forbes' deflected strike doubling the lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa in the first half. McManus and Johnstone scored in the second half to secure the victory for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham. Anyone running illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed shock at the conditions found. It is understood that 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, which will apply to all religious groups operating in unsafe accommodation. The Education Secretary has said she intends to go further and ask Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is Scotland's first new distillery in nearly 200 years. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, the gin production is unique due to its small still and compact operation, fitting into a cowshed. The gin's flavour profile is inspired by local Borders botanicals, reflecting the region's terroir. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery and is set to use local sourcing, aligning with its ethos. The gin's name, Lilliard, is derived from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, near the distillery site.

Harry Whitlam, 22, was fatally injured in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, driving a tractor on private land, reversed into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's grief and hoped that Harry's life would be remembered for the good times they shared.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches after appealing against a four-month ban from football. The ban was imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. Suarez can now attend matches, take part in promotional activities, and will likely make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October. The appeal was successful, with the independent body Cas ruling that FIFA had misapplied its own rules and the sanction was disproportionate. Suarez apologized for the incident, and his legal team argued that the appeal was a success.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved tackling a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event is open to all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Rich and Anna's victory qualified them to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October, which will be replaced with an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. This change may result in job role reductions and the need for employees to train on new processes. The minister, Stephen Hammond, assured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that any reductions in staff numbers will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed the assurances, acknowledging the advantages of the new system but expressing disappointment about the potential reduction in job opportunities at the DVLA.

The passage discusses the EU's disagreement with Hungary over tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University. The Hungarian government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under pressure from European institutions to withdraw the laws, but the minister, Szijjarto, stated that Hungary would not backtrack on these issues, as they belong to national competence. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU rules require unanimous approval for decisions like stripping a member country of its voting rights. Hungary is currently housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and is expected to pass a law on NGOs that could stigmatize them as foreign-backed organizations. The deputy head of the EU Commission, Frans Timmermans, warned of action in coming weeks if there were no positive developments.

The passage announces the casting of Emma Watson as Belle, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou in the live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. The film, set to release on 17 March 2017, will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May. Bill Condon, known for Dreamgirls and Twilight, will direct the movie.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer, passed away suddenly after being diagnosed with a "full English" of cancers. He was known for his wit, writing, and intelligence, and was a giant among journalists. Gill had a controversial writing style, often causing controversy with his articles. He was a columnist at the Sunday Times for 30 years and was known for dictating his copy due to dyslexia. Gill was also a friend to many, including Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens, who described him as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill's illness had prompted his engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he also had two children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, also known as Amraa, was attacked by an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer in Ulan Bator, Mongolia. The attack involved the officer hitting Sukhbaatar over the head with a bottle and kicking him in the face. Sukhbaatar, who frequently wears a swastika symbol on stage, was hospitalized for about 10 days due to the injuries. The Russian embassy denied local press reports of the assault, calling them "distorted". The swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia, not associated with Nazism, and has been used in Mongolian culture and history. The musician's lawyer, father, and band member denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. The case is under investigation, and the suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not arrested due to the injuries not being serious.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday, opposing the airport's expansion plans. The protest involved trespassing on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The group, consisting of men and women, has been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport would be reviewed following the incident.

Glamorgan's total was dominated by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, but Gloucestershire struggled to keep up. Selman's century was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores. Gloucestershire's innings was a question of survival in the evening gloom, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan are being led by Michael Hogan for the first time in the absence of Jacques Rudolph.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August for making threats to kill police officers via the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a murder bid involving an ambush on police, who were allegedly meant to respond to a non-existent crime. Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for firearms offences at the time. The threats were made while he was drunk and on two occasions. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to people facing difficulties. Hughes will be sentenced next week.

Yorkshire, aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, lost to Surrey in a match. After a promising start with Dominic Sibley and Kumar Sangakkara scoring quickly, Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Despite Matthew Waite's 3-48, Yorkshire were left to rue dropping Davies and Rory Burns. After losing Adam Lyth early, Yorkshire were well-placed at 75-2, but Meaker turned the game with his wickets. Surrey's fast bowler Stuart Meaker (3-61) turned the game on its head by ripping out Bairstow, Ballance, and Jack Leaning. Despite Bresnan and Waite's best efforts, Surrey won by 27 runs, with Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressing disappointment.

The passage describes a 56ft trawler that was 6 miles west of South Stack when its onboard pump failed to handle the influx of water. The crew then contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. The Holyhead coastguards and the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the vessel and towing it to Holyhead.

24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, Muir, will not be joining the Scotland team at the Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir is focused on completing her final year of studies and believes she has at least two or three more Olympics in her future. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir's outdoor personal best in the 5,000m is 14 minutes 52.07 seconds, achieved in London.

The passage discusses Liverpool's current situation in the Premier League, their title challenge, and the impact of Steven Gerrard's slip that led to Chelsea winning last season. Liverpool overachieved last season, raising expectations unrealistically, and have lost key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge. The team is struggling to score goals, with Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini as their main frontmen. They are also struggling defensively, with set-piece defense and leadership being major issues. The author, Robbie Savage, believes that Liverpool will struggle against Chelsea due to their superior quality. Despite this, Savage still sees Gerrard as an important player for Liverpool and believes he will continue to play for the team.

The Â£45m facility, to be built in Kilmarnock, will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council plans to name it after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer from Kilmarnock who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, who became an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University, gained fame with his first novel and became known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir". He wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works. McIlvanney was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He died in Glasgow on 5 December. The council leader expressed delight at the opportunity to preserve McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock.

The passage discusses an evacuation near a swimming pool in Gourock, Scotland, due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is believed to be a British one from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets and nearby residents were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. A 500m exclusion zone was also established. Small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services. The mine was moved to a safer place before being dealt with due to its deterioration and the uncertainty of its explosive material content. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the procedures.

The passage discusses the funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have been excluded from the funding. Cycling, which contributed 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding cut by £4m to £25.98m. Badminton, which was set to win a medal in Rio, has had its funding removed, causing concern from its executives. Judo, which also had one bronze medal, has had its funding slightly increased. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The government has confirmed its commitment to Tokyo 2020. UK Sport's approach to elite sport has been successful in previous Olympics, and the ambition to win more medals in Tokyo is a bold one. Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's designated conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The council voted seven to three in favor of the development, citing its potential to boost tourism. The new building will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. Despite 246 letters of support, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, arguing that the altered buildings still retain historic character. English Heritage also opposed the project due to its scale.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was fatally attacked in Brecon while off-duty. Jake Vallely, 24, has been charged with manslaughter. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of involvement. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar after Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge. Vallely was sentenced on 8 December. The victim's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead, and expressed the "unbearable pain" of losing him.

Andrew Travers resigned from his position as Barnet Council's chief executive following an error that led to voters being turned away from 155 polling stations due to their names not being on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The investigation will conclude by the end of May and will examine the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead won the match 2-1 against Wrexham. The first half was disappointing for Gateshead, but they improved in the second half. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick, and Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with another impressive set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading Craig Baxter's cross into the net. Wrexham had several chances but couldn't convert them into goals. The match ended with Gateshead winning 2-1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic welfare of people aged 60 and above. Norway tops the list, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank last.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe, with a target of providing every school with a connection. The project requires building a large constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, which could eventually grow to over 2,000. To achieve this, Airbus is implementing new manufacturing methods similar to those used in car and plane factories, aiming for a production cost of less than a million dollars per unit. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more in a soon-to-open factory complex in Florida. The project requires a significant launch campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked to launch clusters of satellites into orbit. The constellation is expected to be fully operational by the middle of the decade, with just under 300 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020, over 600 by the middle of the decade, and more than 800 by the end of the decade. The UK government's recent spending review has imposed "unprecedented pressure" on Scottish public expenditure, with the Scottish government arguing that cuts since 2010 and the latest spending review will result in a 12.5% reduction in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. The Scottish government claims that £1bn of cuts still need to be made between now and 2020. The Scottish government, led by Finance Secretary Derek Swinney, is determined to defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service from austerity measures. The UK government's Scotland Office responds that the Scottish government will have £390m more spending available next year, and that the UK economy provides a better deal for Scotland than the constitutional alternative favored by the Scottish government. The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when accessing suitable toilet facilities in public places. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which are larger and have additional features to meet the needs of people who use them. Currently, there are over 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners argue that they should be made compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities. The passage also mentions the psychological impact of not having access to appropriate toilet facilities on the whole family. While there are some positive examples of businesses installing Changing Places toilets, such as Arsenal Football Club, there are also logistical and financial barriers to installation. The passage concludes by emphasizing the importance of making toilet facilities accessible to all customers.

A group of Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the fast-food giant forces its Italian franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's denies these claims, stating that they share risks and rewards with their licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint, which alleges that McDonald's abuses its dominant market position, hurting franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission and can launch an investigation if the allegations are found to be valid. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and higher lease premises from the company, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The passage is about a 13-year-old boy named Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. He was due for an operation on his appendix at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, but doctors discovered a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The news shocked his family, but they received global support from people all over the world through a social media campaign started by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram and has since gone viral, with over 79,000 people viewing the updates about Josh. A mystery donor paid for a billboard to be erected at Holywood playing fields, and there has been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for Josh.

The UK government has announced a reorganization of military buildings, including the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales. The barracks, which has been in operation since 1805, has been home to troops who fought in various conflicts, including the Zulu war at Rorke's Drift. The closure has been met with criticism from Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies, who has launched a petition against the decision. Davies has expressed concern about the potential impact on the local military tourism industry and unemployment levels. The reorganization will see a specialist light infantry center created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, with Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire, and a storage depot at Sennybridge also set to close. The ministry has stated that the restructuring is necessary, but has not provided specific details on the potential impact on jobs or the military tourism industry.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. The industry has been marginalized in wider Brexit negotiations due to its low GDP contribution and employment figures. However, many in the industry argue that Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. The UK's fishing industry is heavily reliant on EU member states for market access, and Brexit may involve trade-offs, such as EU member states demanding more access to UK waters in return for continued rights to sell fish to the European market with zero tariffs. The report suggests that many elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas continue to be based on scientific advice. The report also highlights the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if Britain leaves the EU. The passage discusses the revelations made by Edward Snowden regarding the US National Security Agency's (NSA) mass surveillance activities. The NSA has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals. They also have a relationship with nine major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple, which have denied involvement. The NSA's activities are justified as a means to keep Americans secure, but critics argue that the secrecy surrounding these operations raises concerns about privacy and national security. The passage also mentions the US Patriot Act of 2001, which gave American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US. The existence of Prism, a program reportedly established in 2007, has raised concerns about global surveillance and privacy. The EU Justice Commission has expressed concern about the consequences of Prism for EU citizens. Snowden, the source of the leaked documents, acted due to concerns about privacy and the extent of US surveillance.

The venture, OpenAI, is backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, and Indian tech giant Infosys. It aims to conduct AI research free from financial obligations, focusing on a "positive human impact". Scientists warn that AI could pose a threat to humanity, with Musk and Hawking expressing concerns. However, other experts disagree, stating the risk is remote. OpenAI's goal is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, unconstrained by financial returns. They aim for AI to be an extension of human wills, distributed broadly and safely. Only a small fraction of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

Lance Corporal Ben Parkinson, based in Doncaster, was severely injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He has been carrying the Olympic torch since 26 June, receiving thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but can only accept a limited number due to the site's restrictions. Despite a brain injury that affected his speech, he walked nearly half an hour with the torch, supported by an assistant. Parkinson is known for his determination and sense of humor, spending 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and raising money for military charities. His mother, Diane, has received over 5,000 friend requests and thousands of messages of support. Facebook advised Parkinson to create a page or use subscribe to handle the increased traffic. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame during its journey to the Olympic Games opening ceremony in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, with 46.2 million people living in poverty, a figure that remained unchanged after three years of increases. Real median income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010.

The passage discusses Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer from Somerset who moved to Lancashire (the Red Rose) in 2013. He has signed a new deal with the club until 2019. Buttler is known for his short-format specialization and has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers in the game, stating that Buttler's presence in the T20 Blast final at Edgbaston was a factor in their win. Buttler, who is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The four decommissioned Type 22 frigates - HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall - are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest in acquiring these ships, with final bids due in late February and March. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the country's ship recycling capabilities. Penny Mordaunt, the Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, advocates for preserving at least one frigate as a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. No proposals to preserve the ships as museums have been submitted. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with advanced weapons systems. They were known for their excellent command and control facilities, making them ideal flagships on deployments. Last year,

Fiji, a former British colony, has experienced racial and political tensions since 1987, leading to several coups and international isolation. The 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew the Indian-dominated coalition, resulting in a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian supremacy that was later withdrawn. The 2000 coup, led by businessman George Speight, held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and cabinet hostage for weeks, causing significant economic and reputational damage. The 2006 military takeover was the fourth coup in 20 years, and Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 for lack of progress towards democracy. The government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and re-admission to the Commonwealth. Syria has been accused of using barrel bombs in Aleppo, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reporting 246 deaths in the last five days. The Syrian government denies this and claims it is defending against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government has also been accused of missing a deadline to hand over its chemical weapons, with only 4% of the stockpile having left the country so far. The US and Russia have set deadlines for the complete transfer and destruction of Syria's chemical weapons by 1 March and the end of June respectively. The Syrian government has stated it is committed to all its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The 2014 Booker Prize shortlist includes Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others," a novel set in 1960s Calcutta, as the 5/2 favorite. The prize is open to all English-writing authors, regardless of nationality. The shortlist also features Howard Jacobson's "J," Ali Smith's "How To Be Both," Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." Jacobson, a former Booker winner, is nominated for his futuristic love story "J." The novel explores a world where the past is not spoken about and is shrouded in suspicion. Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others" begins in Calcutta in 1967, focusing on the secrets and rivalries within a family against a backdrop of political activism. The man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide whether to grant or dismiss the appeal. The man has young children and his spouse is also in the public eye. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by the man, but he argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The man had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. They had a text message exchange in December 2011 discussing a "three-way" with AB's partner, CD, and met for a three-way sexual encounter. The man approached the Sun on Sunday with the story, but a High Court judge initially refused to impose an injunction. The man appealed and two appeal court judges ruled in his favour, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. News Group Newspapers, publishers of the Sun on Sunday,

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, was bought in August 2022 for £345.5m. The new owners, Crown Estates, plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, stated that the new owners have met with the council to clarify "potential planning questions". The council aims to enhance the view of Fosse Park from the city, currently dominated by backs of sheds. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, mentioned that they plan to address parking and congestion issues, as well as improve the quality of common areas and facilities to make Fosse Park a better location.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, but Disney is reviewing its content. The film was initially due for release in Malaysia on Thursday, but a new release date has not been announced. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification". Local cinema chains are offering refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance. The decision to review the film courted criticism from netizens.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people in Southampton are required to obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost up to £1,000 but carries a maximum fine of £20,000. Despite this, many landlords are deterred due to the cost. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants often express concerns about eviction and living in poorly maintained properties due to the lack of affordable housing. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance. The licensing regime applies to properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett.

Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin, leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil respectively, are seeking to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil, with 44 seats, wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael, with 50 seats, sees a role for them. A commission to consider Irish Water's future is being considered. No party has been able to form a majority government since the last election, with TDs failing to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, experienced a fire that quickly got out of control. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital by helicopter. The fire started on one of the car decks around 27km from Mallorca. The cause of the fire is unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to help. The rescued passengers were taken to the Puglia ferry and expected to arrive in Palma de Mallorca in a few hours. Psychologists were deployed to provide counseling. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire. The ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time. The captain initially did not believe an evacuation was necessary but ordered one due to the intense fire.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs discovered individuals, including students, who voted twice, a criminal offence. The Commission suggested joining individual electoral registers run by councils to identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% actually voting, the highest turnout since 1997. There was a surge in applications to register to vote after Theresa May called the snap poll on 18 April, with 2.9 million applications received. Concerns about duplicate applications persist due to the lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The Commission estimated that 30% to 70% of applications may be duplicates, causing administration and financial burdens. The Commission recommended clearer information on registration sites, including a verification function, and urgent action to address the issue. Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL star and University of Nebraska player, is believed to have committed suicide. In the 1990s, he played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers but was plagued by legal issues and anger problems. He was sent to prison for assault and served a long term for another assault conviction. Phillips was accused of killing his cellmate and was placed in a cell alone. A judge found enough evidence to try him in the death of Damion Soward. The cause of Phillips' suicide is unknown. His coach at Nebraska described him as intelligent and having good qualities but struggling with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century, was promoted to lance corporal and awarded an honor by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, receives payment for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. He has also assisted in switching on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League semi-first leg, with goals from Dejan Lovren, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho. The match was marked by Liverpool's resilience and determination, overcoming a 2-0 deficit to turn the game around. Jurgen Klopp's impact on the team was evident, with his inspiring words and the team's ability to turn doubts into belief. The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with the fans playing a significant role in the team's performance. Liverpool's next challenge will be to overcome Sevilla in the semi-finals, with the Europa League final and a potential return to the Champions League also within reach. Klopp has emphasized the importance of winning and respecting the 'This Is Anfield' sign before touching it.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee held a meeting in London where the UK government committed to regular monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to share analysis and updates on negotiations with Brussels. The UK government aims to work together with the devolved administrations to get the best deal for the UK. However, the Scottish government's representative, Mr. Russell, expressed concern about the lack of clarity from the UK government on its strategic intentions regarding EU market access and the customs union. He emphasized the importance of membership in the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes the High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government intends to oppose this in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The passage discusses a study on 13 cloned sheep, including Dolly the sheep, which were cloned from the same adult ewe. These sheep are among the most closely monitored and studied animals in the world, with the fate of the science of cloning depending on their health and aging. The cloning process involves extracting DNA from an adult animal's fully differentiated cell, raising concerns about transferring "age-memory" to the next generation. This could make cloned animals appear older and develop diseases associated with aging at a younger age. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old due to a virus and osteoarthritis, which raised concerns about premature aging. The study involved putting the dollies through extensive tests and assessments, including joint X-rays and fMRI scans, to determine if cloned animals have higher rates of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week. Currently, the dollies appear to be in good health,

- Unbeaten favourite, trained by John Gosden, won a race after walking the course. She beat the second-placed horse, Vintage Folly, by a length and three-quarters.
- The horse will not run in the Oaks at Epsom, instead going to Chantilly. Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Oaks.
- Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas, with Jim Crowley's mount winning comfortably from Magical Memory in second, and Comicas third.
- Shutter Speed, who last ran at Newbury and beat Enable into third, won her fifth Musidora race for Gosden and Dettori. Dettori commented that the ground was very soft and hard work for the horse.
- Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding whether to run in the Derby trial.
- BBC Sport horse racing correspondent

The pound has been experiencing volatility, initially slipping against the dollar and euro but then recovering and falling again. It has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis, according to the "volatility index". The Leave campaign argues that the pound is retreating to March levels. Two recent polls show the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain has fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. The pound has lost more than 2% in two sessions, and Asian stock markets have also reacted negatively due to concerns about the economic impact of leaving the EU. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller.

The Iron are currently in sixth place in the National League, just one point outside the play-offs. They lost to Barrow, who have won nine consecutive league games, but manager Cowley remains positive. He acknowledges the team's impressive performance so far, despite being a part-time team, and expresses determination to enjoy and embrace their toughest challenge yet.

The passage discusses the proposed shift in planning responsibilities from the Planning Service, an agency under Stormont's environment department, to local councils in Northern Ireland. This change is expected to take effect from April 2015, aiming to democratize the planning system by allowing elected politicians to make planning decisions. However, there are concerns about the potential for discrimination and close relationships between developers and political parties, which could lead to a laissez-faire system. To ensure fairness and transparency, a strict code of conduct will need to be enforced, and there is a call for increased public knowledge of political party donations, particularly in light of the potential financial consequences for developers and objectors. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to implement measures to shed more light on political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg, which had to be amputated. The cat survived and is now learning to walk again. The incident has raised concerns about the lack of licensing for air weapons in Scotland, with a majority of respondents opposing the proposed scheme in a 2021 consultation. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool has signed Belgian international Christian Benteke on a long-term contract for an undisclosed fee, triggering a release clause in his contract. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, was previously signed by Liverpool for £7m in 2012. The club has struggled for goals in recent seasons, finishing sixth in the Premier League last season. Benteke's signing is aimed at reviving Liverpool's attack, along with other new signings Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, Danny Ings, and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield, while former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is excited about the addition of Benteke's "massive presence" up front.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly used in schools (68% in primary and 69% in secondary), there's no clear evidence of improved academic results. The rapid growth of tablet use is also seen at home. The study reported that 9% of schools have individual tablets for every pupil, with academy schools showing the highest use. The number of tablets in schools is expected to rise from 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While it's challenging to isolate the impact of technology on academic results, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers, like tablets, are particularly useful for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The study also highlighted that tablets are part of everyday life for young people, with many describing themselves as "internet addicts" and using devices for social media or watching videos before bed.

The Museum of Liverpool's exhibition, 'Growing Up in the City', features 25 evocative photographs that depict the life of children in the city over more than 100 years. The images, spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, provide a snapshot of childhood and a social history of Liverpool. They show children at play, special occasions, and also illustrate the work of youngsters. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes a portrait of the Rollo family from 1887 and a 1900 image of a young maid from a well-to-do Liverpool family. The exhibition aims to show both the good and bad experiences of childhood.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow and joined their rivals in the National League. He could potentially face his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been signed by Barrow from Sligo Rovers. He was recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams and is subject to international clearance. Barrow is currently in the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia, a poor South American country, that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including 30 years in jail for child homicide. The law was approved by Congress and signed into law by the Vice-President, despite the President being unavailable due to travel. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia work to support their families, often in hazardous conditions. The law aims to eradicate extreme poverty and is not in line with international conventions on child labor, but the International Labour Organization is studying its compliance.

50-year-old actress O'Donnell fell ill at home, experiencing sudden nausea, aches, and chest pain. She looked up symptoms online, found "women's heart attack symptoms," and took aspirin. The next day, she visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent after finding a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell had a "widow maker" heart attack, a type of attack known for its severity. She did not call emergency services but later warned women to recognize heart attack symptoms and call 911. The Rosie Show, where she hosted, was cancelled due to low ratings.

16-year-old Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was stabbed to death at a well-organized party in Kenton, Kent, on Saturday night. He was not involved in an initial altercation with a group of youths but was later targeted and stabbed in an alleyway. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A man aged 21 has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed. A third boy aged 14 is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses a reorganization of patient diagnosis by GPs and specialists in Wales, inspired by Denmark's improved cancer diagnosis system. The issue was long waiting times for patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms, which led to poor cancer survival statistics in Denmark. The new model in Denmark has three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms GPs can't diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have resulted in better organization, reduced waiting times, and improved survival rates in Denmark. The Welsh Cancer Network's medical director, Dr. Tom Crosby, has been impressed with Denmark's collaboration between GPs and specialists to achieve better diagnoses.

31 March 2014: Powys Council to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest or breaching estate agents, replacing the disbanded OFT. Powys to receive £170,000 annually for the service. Complaints will still go to local authorities' trading standards, referring breached cases to Powys. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, aiming to demonstrate Powys' capacity for external contracts.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshuffle the healthcare workforce, with nurses potentially taking on more tasks due to doctor and pharmacist shortages. The Nuffield Trust found examples of nurses filling in for doctors and GPs. Unions caution against this as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for good quality training for doctors and adequate funding for training courses. The report highlights the changing nature of care, with more focus on long-term conditions, and the need for more staff to support doctors.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First said it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal, and they hope to have a full service running by the evening commute. The police and staff worked together to manage the situation and recovery.

The NRW estimates that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout will die annually due to the tidal lagoon, but TLP disputes these figures, claiming they have no clear scientific basis. TLP argues that NRW's figures are based on "what if" scenarios and lack evidence. They present their own computer modeling estimating a "worst case scenario" of 2% impact on all fish species. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary is seeking clarity on the UK's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and asserts that their figures are based on the best available evidence after consulting with the developer and independent experts.

The passage discusses the announcement of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, led by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This body aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move is significant as Northern Ireland's agri-food industry employs almost 100,000 people in sectors like farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The new body will address the need for better coordination of current marketing activities, as indicated by industry representatives. However, it may have implications for other organizations, including the Agriculture Minister's department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees, including 40,000 in Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1, particularly those from the island of Ireland. The public is invited to participate in planting the trees, with the charity providing saplings and encouraging them to wear welly boots. The project aims to create a place for wildlife to thrive and for people to walk, relax, and reflect.

Hilary, a crime novelist, won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival. The award-winning book, "Someone Else's Skin", is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. The book was praised for its emotionally exhausting and powerful story, as well as its finely written and tightly written plot. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky was recognized for her impact on female writers and her role in establishing Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers around the world.

Worcestershire CCC, led by director of cricket Steve Rhodes, aims to have left-arm batsman and spinner Mitch Santner back in their squad for the 2017 season. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, was unfortunate to break his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, which hindered their hopes of qualifying for the tournament. Santner enjoyed his time at Worcestershire with the team and is looking forward to making up for lost time in the 2017 season. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the entire 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was in Ukraine at the time, and Pring's family believes he was murdered. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Pring, tried to claim his assets soon after his death. The couple met online in 2006 and married in 2007. Pring was hit by a car with no lights, speeding at 75mph, and witnesses described the killing as a deliberate act. The Ukrainian police closed the case initially but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011. Ziuzina sold Pring's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate and was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. The coroner recorded

Charlie Fearns, a 12-year-old boy from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle, America for an experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital, as the UK does not have this treatment available. Charlie has been battling illness since the age of three and had a third relapse in April, leaving no other treatment options in the UK. The first T-Cell transplant did not work, leaving the family heartbroken. However, an anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, which was confirmed via email from the hospital on Wednesday. The treatment will start as soon as possible, and the family expects to find out the date next week.

Apple has been accused of allowing third-party software to steal intimate photos from celebrities' iCloud accounts. To prevent this, Apple is introducing a two-step verification system that requires an extra step after typing the username and password, a four-digit code texted to a trusted mobile number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app, and a 14-character recovery key for account access. This system was not previously in place, allowing attackers to download a complete back-up of data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The software's owner, Vladimir Katalov, has acknowledged that Apple's changes make his program ineffective. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves revealed that the terms of a deal, where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Old Boys, are still being finalized. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity winner, will become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points behind a play-off spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has committed to investing £10,000 a week. Billericay has recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who also chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee plans to meet with Mr. Ashley at the company's base in Shirebrook, with the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage being key issues. The committee has committed to transparency and will meet in public at Westminster. Sports Direct has not yet agreed to the offered dates for the meeting, and if they fail to respond, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. The company had previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The report, "Putin. War," was intended to be written by a group led by Ilya Yashin, but was never completed. It primarily focuses on the Russian-language report, titled "Putin. War," which is based on facts that have been reported in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in 2014 and conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine. The report alleges that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, with Russian soldiers and equipment playing a decisive role in securing victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report also presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit that they were directed by Russian generals in the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report's authors claim that Russian spending on the conflict is estimated at 53 billion roubles (Â£665m; $1bn). The opposition plans to extend the initial print run of only 2,000

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to publish the Article 50 letter, which includes the UK's intention to return powers to the devolved administrations. The Welsh First Minister, Carwyn Jones, expressed frustration that he hadn't seen the letter before it was published and that the devolved administrations were not consulted in its drafting. The UK government aims to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but the Welsh Secretary, Alun Cairns, defended the government's actions, stating that the Prime Minister has been in Wales three times in the last six weeks and that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. The letter mentions Wales and the expectation is that the outcome of the process will be a significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration. However, the specific powers that the UK government wants to see devolved to Wales is still a mystery.

Two cars were damaged in a incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community.
