21-year-old Australian tennis player, Nick Kyrgios, defeated world number 29, Mike Berrett, 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won the Japan Open on Sunday and is close to the top 10. However, he admitted to feeling tired and bored, which may have contributed to his quieter demeanor compared to his usual self. The travel and playing conditions in Japan, including a long ride to the courts, are believed to have affected his performance. This is not the first time Kyrgios has had issues with the travel and conditions at the Shanghai Masters, as he was fined $1,500 (£984) for a foul-mouthed outburst at the tournament last year.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of expanding the HPV vaccination program in Wales to include boys, as the virus is sexually transmitted and can cause head and neck cancers. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. Charities and organizations are calling for the vaccination to be rolled out to boys due to the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunization before making a decision. The HPV virus causes 5% of the global cancer burden, and expanding the vaccination program could help stem the tide of these cancers.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Calder High School, passed away after a battle with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He had been documenting his journey on social media since his diagnosis in August. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was an avid Rangers fan. He attended his prom briefly before being hospitalized and received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Jak's family set up a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in his memory. A special football match is being held to raise more funds for charity.

Egypt won the match 1-0 against Uganda, with the winning goal scored by Mohamed Salah in the 89th minute, assisted by Abdallah El Said. The match was played in Port-Gentil, with Egypt playing with a resolute defense against Uganda's offensive play. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside, and Egypt had several chances to score but failed to convert. The win means Egypt plays Ghana in the last round of group games for top spot, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College, is also unused. The decision comes after a study by Network Rail, which found that Skelmersdale could get two direct trains to Liverpool per hour under the council's plans. The council, which owns Glenburn Sports College, aims to improve connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale was designated a new town in 1961 and is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.

The passage mentions that plants were discovered during a search of a warehouse in Ashbourne on Saturday morning. These plants were found in an "elaborate grow house". A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, has been arrested and is in custody. The motive for the attack is not yet clear. The woman was taken to a specialist clinic after undergoing an emergency operation. Police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, Warwick, and Wisconsin universities found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. This contradicts the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for more money. The study compared full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females, eliminating any impact from part-time workers earning less. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The research also found no evidence for the idea that women are reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a stereotype. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, which is thought to be the only country to systematically record whether employees had asked for a pay rise and why they had or had not done so. The findings suggest there is some element of pure discrimination against women. The study also found differences

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but all council-owned sites have been deemed unsuitable due to factors such as site size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. The council has not given up and is still exploring options, with the only alternatives being the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes after the cemeteries are full. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, is offering an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to access online information from site signs and posters, view videos and band interviews on phones and tablets. The festival features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The director, Caroline Maclennan, stated that this feature will enhance the festival experience for local visitors and provide global interaction, allowing people to access information, interviews, tickets, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated leading up to the festival and during the event.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, and there were no significant underlying health issues. The horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, this was the first time he collapsed. The British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the cause of such incidents and prevent them.

The 15-year-old girl, who has learning difficulties, met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who later changed her name to Davina, is accused of raping the girl while two others were asleep. The girl recalled the incident, having only consumed a can and a half of Foster's beer. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire. The girl attempted suicide last summer, and Ayrton will be sentenced on 4 March, to be held at a male prison in Winchester due to safety concerns. Protocols have been set for her detention, and she has not undergone any physical changes or taken medication related to her sexuality.

The Serbs, consisting of Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares, defeated world number one Novak Djokovic and Juan Martin del Potro 6-4, 6-4 in the Rio Olympics. This loss came a day after Djokovic was eliminated in the singles round by del Potro. Djokovic, a 12-time Grand Slam champion, had previously won the Toronto Masters title before the Olympics.

20+ competitors will participate in Saturday's carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. Contestants include carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US. They must use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh player, has not played since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is close to a return and is undergoing a pre-season training phase. He aims to take each week as it comes and is hopeful of returning to the field at the beginning of February, with a possible extension of a couple of weeks. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign against Ireland in Dublin on 7 February. Webb, who has been capped 16 times for Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. He turned down offers from other teams to stay at his home region, where he made his debut in 2007.

Two men were arrested near the US-Canada border in Washington state for attempting to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody immediately, while the other, Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their alleged involvement in the smuggling operation. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The incident occurred in a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 counseling sessions in the past year compared to around 2,400 in 2011-12. The true extent of online bullying is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have been affected, experiencing torment, abuse, and fear of attending school. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children from bullying, which can worsen without intervention. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, to raise awareness and combat the problem. A young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being targeted online and the emotional distress it caused. They advised other young people to seek help and stand up for themselves when dealing with bullying.

The Israeli government, led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is considering postponing a vote on authorizing new housing units in the settlement of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot in East Jerusalem, following a US decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction. The resolution, which passed with 14 votes in favor, is considered a blow to Israel as it views East Jerusalem as part of its capital, while the Palestinians want it as the capital of their future state. The US accused Israel of helping draft the resolution and pushing for its passage, which Israel denies. Israel has also recalled its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister in response to the resolution. US Secretary of State John Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict later on Wednesday.

The passage is about Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, which was celebrated with various events and tributes. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, met staff and viewed an exhibition at Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office. She also officially opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and met pupils from the six schools involved in its decoration. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn wished her a happy birthday at Prime Minister's Questions. Prince William spoke about his mother's duty, service, tolerance, and commitment to others, which have been a guiding example for him. He also addressed the recent headlines about him being a "work-shy" prince, stating that he accepts criticism but doesn't let it influence his decisions. The Queen will light a beacon in the evening to mark the milestone birthday, and US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle. Cheltenham Town lost 2-0 to West Ham United in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham, while Cheltenham had few chances. The match took place at West Ham's Upton Park, where they won the previous meeting four years ago. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died after a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, was found guilty of causing death by careless driving. He pleaded guilty at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. Werner's family, who were staying in a cottage near Bala, saw no value in him being sent to jail as they accepted it was a momentary lapse. Werner was remorseful but had no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British man from Southall, west London, is accused of being one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from the Syria conflict. He, under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group of British fighters affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was known for his online presence, posting videos and pictures of his personal jihad in Syria. He was involved in fundraising, propaganda, and appeals for donations. However, he faked his own death and tried to slip back into the UK unnoticed, leading to his arrest and prosecution at the Old Bailey. Khawaja is currently facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in the conflict.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish 8th in the table. Barnsley has signed him as their third player for the upcoming League One play-off final at Wembley. The caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and defensive skills, stating that he will fit well with the team's playing style. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season.

Volunteers are clearing bottles from Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, believed to be from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End. The bottles, sealed but some leaking, pose a risk to wildlife. Other coves are also affected, causing concern for marine life. The National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation, with the bottles being cleared away by the trust. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from any more washed-up bottles.

A car crash happened on the A9 near Berriedale, Caithness, at 14:00, injuring several people. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 to Melvich. Police are investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Wanderers, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and securing promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite's contribution was particularly significant towards the end of the campaign. He has since signed a new contract with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage describes a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour over their cooperation on Brexit-related issues. The Lib Dems, led by Lord Oates, accused Labour of being willing to concede on issues like EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, Labour, led by Baroness Smith, argued that the Lib Dems were giving people false hope. The two parties had previously worked together to defeat the government on these issues, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected the amendments. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for "grandstanding" and building false hope, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with the Conservatives on Brexit. The passage also mentions that the two parties have a history of forming alliances to impose government defeats on various bills. The election issue of foreign policy and the role of UK's defence forces at home and abroad includes defence spending and the UK's military capabilities. The Conservative and Labour parties have made significant cuts to their armed forces, reducing the size of the regular Army, the Royal Navy's fleet, and the RAF's front-line fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen behind other nations in defence spending, with only two parties committed to meeting the 2% GDP target. The MoD has reason to be nervous as further cuts could lead to significant savings in defence, potentially impacting the UK's credibility as a key ally. The Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent, while Labour, the Liberal Democrats, the SNP, and the Greens have different views on nuclear deterrence and CASD. The Royal Navy's two new aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth and the Prince of Wales, face challenges in crewing and equipping them with the F-3

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with additional fees totaling £106.8m, including a £34m payment to Neymar's parents. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated. A judge in Spain has ruled to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona has made a £13.55m tax declaration to defend their reputation, but they maintain the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored 15 goals in total for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, a 66-year-old man who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family and Age UK have called for retired drivers to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations. Newman's car was heading north on the southbound carriageway when it collided with a van Luciw was traveling in. Luciw's colleague, Andy Harrington, was also in the van and survived with serious injuries. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The passage discusses the safety concerns of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in Scotland. Two original review group members resigned due to a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report, which concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and informed choices, and that reporting of adverse events be mandatory. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the power to ban the procedures, as that lies with the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, who had suffered complications from the surgery, resigned from the review group earlier this year. A consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh

Muir, a 23-year-old, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record for 5000 meters by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan, who had raised concerns about the criteria for record-breaking attempts, acknowledged Muir's achievement. She had earlier expressed doubts about whether Muir's race met the requirements, as it was a mixed 3K race where only Muir finished the 5K. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's ability and potential to win world medals, noting that her time was similar to McColgan's own record-breaking race 25 years ago. Muir had previously broken her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

In the 2016 Rio Olympics equestrian event, Jung won the gold medal aboard Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who contracted an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and America's Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, 47, competed despite being placed in an induced coma 10 months prior, but his medal bid was ruined by a poor cross-country performance. He finished 12th after leading after dressage but incurring time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished 9th on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

30-year-old British tennis player Andy Murray won his fourth round match at Wimbledon against Italian 29th seed Fognini. Murray won 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to seal the victory. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray was not at his best but managed to get through the match. The match was tense and Murray avoided a long, drawn-out contest in the third set. Fognini was on the defensive in the fourth set and Murray showed all his fighting qualities to save set points. Murray will have a day's break before his next match.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death. Despite police finding several people still at the bar when they arrived, alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST, as shown by till receipts. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and her partner James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern about their record and fined O'Neill £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge also mentioned that O'Neill had an appalling record and that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched their manifesto, 'Real Partnership', which includes plans to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and ensure no group is worse off due to Brexit. Nesbitt emphasized that the election is a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP and Sinn Féin's time in Stormont. He defended his comments about the election being a referendum and expressed confidence in the party's position. Nesbitt also criticized the DUP and Sinn Féin for incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, announced that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales in implementing automatic pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences. This includes posthumous pardons for those who have passed away and the option for living men to apply for a pardon. The law, known as 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing and aims to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, who have historically faced different treatment compared to their counterparts in England and Wales. The minister has secured executive agreement to introduce a legislative consent motion for the pardon of convictions related to abolished sexual offences, with the aim of addressing past wrongs and providing earlier resolution than an assembly bill. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

23-year-old Scottish runner Laura Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m event, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12. This result improved upon Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60. Muir also holds the Scottish records for the 1500m and mile events. She is currently preparing for the British trials in Birmingham on June 24-26 to secure an Olympics spot for Great Britain in Rio. Muir recently completed her fourth year of veterinary studies and started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, last week. She will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm.
The passage mentions that the user has access to pictures from the top 26 beaches in Scotland, ranked for their water quality.

The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a Russian spy who died in London in 2006 after consuming tea laced with a radioactive substance, polonium-210. Horwell believes the Russian state was involved in Litvinenko's murder, with reasons including harm and death, and that the only credible explanation is state involvement. However, he clarified that this does not imply Russian President Vladimir Putin's involvement or the order of the murder. Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticisms of the Russian government, including allegations of murder and corruption, could have been seen as treachery. The suspects left a trail of polonium and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Despite attempts to extradite the suspects, they remain in Russia, and the inquiry is adjourn

Steve Smith, at 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, following Michael Clarke's retirement. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests last summer. He has played in 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary issues. Warner has matured and developed into a senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting on 20 August.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights, stating that he is "passionate" about them and will prioritize equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people. He previously voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, specifically the spousal veto issue, but now supports equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

In 2015, Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in the UK, leading to the loss of 450 jobs. However, Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical firm, has since taken over the plant to produce its pharmaceuticals. Accord aims to fill many of the jobs with former Sanofi staff and is confident the investment will have a positive impact on the local economy. The move is welcomed by Newcastle City Council, which sees it as a boost to the local science and healthcare sector and a strengthening of the region's reputation. Accord Healthcare produces over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance, and heads of the chief executive's office (Ciaran Monaghan) and human resources and customer services (Ewan Sutherland), are all leaving the local authority. Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. The SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, criticized the departures as indicative of the council's struggle to retain senior staff and expects more departures in the future. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the departing staff for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, has decided to stop road racing on Hondas this year after crashing at the TT and facing mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement but later clarified that he's not giving up on racing or road racing. However, he won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's lack of competitiveness, as decided by the team after further testing at Cadwell. Martin expressed his desire to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorship posts in the recent Nigerian elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has been in power since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari is set to be inaugurated on 29 May, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll. The PDP's decline was further reinforced by the election results for governors and state assemblies, as they lost in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and in Adamawa, one of the states badly hit by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC also failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production and starve the federal government of oil revenue. The passage discusses allegations made by environmental lobby group Mighty against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. The claims include turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and claims to account for less than 1% of the global market. Mighty's report also accuses Olam and Temasek of potentially linking Singapore's state fund to the haze if the claims of sourcing from rogue palm oil producers are proven. Olam's CEO, Sunny Verghese, asserts that the company has a vigorous sourcing policy with zero tolerance for burning, deforestation, and illegal labor practices. However, Mighty's report claims that Olam's current suppliers may not all meet the company's strict requirements, and the vetting and verification process will take several more years. The passage mentions that a restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law was implemented, permitting dogs to dine outdoors. The law change allowed for this unusual service, as shown in a clip.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is uncertain due to a knee injury, having only played from the bench in the last two games. Striker David Nugent might return after missing the previous game due to a groin issue. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a comeback after scoring a late equalizer in the recent Huddersfield match.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube following Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version. The ban, imposed in 2012 due to a controversial US-made film, was lifted after Google agreed to a deal with the Pakistan government. Google will now directly receive requests from the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to block offending material. However, Google will not automatically grant government requests for content removal, and such requests will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban was criticized for its potential impact on freedom of speech and expression in Pakistan.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, a member of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and his eligibility to participate in the presidential election to replace Sepp Blatter. Scala, who is Swiss-Italian, excused himself from the 2015 elections due to a conflict of interest as he shared nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. However, LFA boss Musa Bility threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, as the same process was not followed ahead of the 2015 elections. Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, argues that there is no conflict of interest as there is no provision in the relevant regulations of Fifa that a member of the ad-hoc electoral committee has the same nationality as a candidate. The election will take place in Fifa's headquarters in Zurich and involves five candidates, including Prince Ali of Jordan, Frenchman Jerome Champagne, Bahrain's Sheikh Salman

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were fatally injured at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area when a flashover explosion occurred, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon, and forensic inquiries, including a forensic search at the company and obtaining witness statements, are ongoing. The Health and Safety Executive will also be gathering evidence.

Tunisia was facing expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against CAF, but was allowed to participate after apologizing. Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but the ban was overturned after reducing a fine from $1m to $50,000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Tunisia had a dispute with CAF over a controversial penalty in the 2015 quarter-finals, leading to a demand for an apology by CAF or disqualification. Tunisia and CAF reconciled, and Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

In the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1 against Manchester City. The match was marred by a mass brawl, with City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho receiving four-match and three-match bans respectively for violent conduct. Aguero, 28, was sent off for a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, while Fernandinho was involved in the scuffle that followed. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the incident. Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a cancer screening program in the Rhondda Cynon Taf area of Wales. The program aims to identify people with cancer symptoms early through regular screening. The program has been successful in detecting cancer at an early stage, with 40% of those screened in the Nantgarw area having been diagnosed with cancer. However, some people may not have any symptoms and still need to be screened. The program is expected to continue in the future, with the aim of identifying cancer at an even earlier stage. The program has been praised for its effectiveness in detecting cancer early, which can improve treatment outcomes and survival rates. The program is part of a wider effort to improve cancer care in Wales.

England won the match against Pakistan with a significant margin at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England's Joe Root scored 254 in the first innings and 71 in the second, while also taking four catches and a wicket. Root's performance was praised for its control and discipline. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50. The series is expected to be tight, with Pakistan playing a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test.

Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has named Rob Howley as an interim coach for the New Zealand tour. Forwards coach Steve McBryde will lead the team as head coach for the third time, having previously led Wales tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his excitement and honor to represent his country and lead the team overseas. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde, and they hope to confirm the full management team by next week. Welsh coaches' involvement in the Lions' tour is expected to benefit the national team and provide a valuable opportunity for their development.

The passage is about a football match between Southampton and Hull City. The match ended with Hull City winning 2-1, which was their first win since August 20. The match was marred by injuries to Hull's starting strikers and Snodgrass' tireless running lifted his team-mates. The match was played in front of a sparse crowd due to Hull's poor form and the international break. The win ended Southampton's six-game losing streak and they remain in the bottom three.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, at around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist, who is locally resident, was not injured in the crash. The tractor driver was unharmed. The road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction for investigation. Lincolnshire Police is appealing for witnesses to come forward.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, citing the need to end the crisis before early elections in June. However, this decision was criticized by the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of covert recordings allegedly showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and a murder cover-up. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev accused the government of wiretapping 20,000 people, including politicians, journalists, and religious leaders, and of corruption at the highest levels. The government denied these accusations, and the crisis has put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. The club, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is struggling to maintain their position and has lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and emphasizes the importance of the club's history and the impact of the 'Swansea Way'. The club has lost several players but is aiming to replace them adequately.

The Daggers, Dagenham & Redbridge, reached League One in 2010 and 2007 respectively. Dagenham reached the Football League for the first time in 2007 but are now returning to the National League under manager John Still. Dagenham has the worst goal difference in League Two and has conceded 20 more goals this season than last term. John Still, who returned for his third spell at Dagenham in December, is committed to helping the club gain promotion from the National League next season. Dagenham's loss leaves Leyton Orient two points adrift of the play-off spots, four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role. Orient interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games to secure play-off spots.

36-year-old former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won multiple trophies with the club, left for MLS side LA Galaxy in 2015. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but decided it was too soon. He is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

Morton won the match 3-1 against Alloa Athletic. McManus scored twice, with Forbes' deflected strike doubling the lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa in the first half. McManus and Johnstone scored in the second half to secure the victory for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham. Anyone running illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed shock at the conditions found. It is understood that 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, which will apply to all religious groups operating in unsafe accommodation. The Education Secretary has said she intends to go further and ask Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is Scotland's first new distillery in nearly 200 years. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, the gin production is unique due to its small still and compact operation, fitting into a cowshed. The gin's flavour profile is inspired by local Borders botanicals, reflecting the region's terroir. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery and is set to use local sourcing, aligning with its ethos. The gin's name, Lilliard, is derived from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, near the distillery site.

Harry Whitlam, 22, was fatally injured in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, driving a tractor on private land, reversed into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's grief and hoped that Harry's life would be remembered for the good times they shared.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches after appealing against a four-month ban from football. The ban was imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. Suarez can now attend matches, take part in promotional activities, and will likely make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October. The appeal was successful, with the independent body Cas ruling that FIFA had misapplied its own rules and the sanction was disproportionate. Suarez apologized for the incident, and his legal team argued that the appeal was a success.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved tackling a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event is open to all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Rich and Anna's victory qualified them to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October, which will be replaced with an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. This change may result in job role reductions and the need for employees to train on new processes. The minister, Stephen Hammond, assured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that any reductions in staff numbers will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed the assurances, acknowledging the advantages of the new system but expressing disappointment about the potential reduction in job opportunities at the DVLA.

The passage discusses the EU's disagreement with Hungary over tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University. The Hungarian government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under pressure from European institutions to withdraw the laws, but the minister, Szijjarto, stated that Hungary would not backtrack on these issues, as they belong to national competence. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU rules require unanimous approval for decisions like stripping a member country of its voting rights. Hungary is currently housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and is expected to pass a law on NGOs that could stigmatize them as foreign-backed organizations. The deputy head of the EU Commission, Frans Timmermans, warned of action in coming weeks if there were no positive developments.

The passage announces the casting of Emma Watson as Belle, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou in the live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. The film, set to release on 17 March 2017, will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May. Bill Condon, known for Dreamgirls and Twilight, will direct the movie.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer, passed away suddenly after being diagnosed with a "full English" of cancers. He was known for his wit, writing, and intelligence, and was a giant among journalists. Gill had a controversial writing style, often causing controversy with his articles. He was a columnist at the Sunday Times for 30 years and was known for dictating his copy due to dyslexia. Gill was also a friend to many, including Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens, who described him as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill's illness had prompted his engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he also had two children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, also known as Amraa, was attacked by an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer in Ulan Bator, Mongolia. The attack involved the officer hitting Sukhbaatar over the head with a bottle and kicking him in the face. Sukhbaatar, who frequently wears a swastika symbol on stage, was hospitalized for about 10 days due to the injuries. The Russian embassy denied local press reports of the assault, calling them "distorted". The swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia, not associated with Nazism, and has been used in Mongolian culture and history. The musician's lawyer, father, and band member denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. The case is under investigation, and the suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not arrested due to the injuries not being serious.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday, opposing the airport's expansion plans. The protest involved trespassing on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The group, consisting of men and women, has been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport would be reviewed following the incident.

Glamorgan's total was dominated by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, but Gloucestershire struggled to keep up. Selman's century was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores. Gloucestershire's innings was a question of survival in the evening gloom, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan are being led by Michael Hogan for the first time in the absence of Jacques Rudolph.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August for making threats to kill police officers via the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a murder bid involving an ambush on police, who were allegedly meant to respond to a non-existent crime. Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for firearms offences at the time. The threats were made while he was drunk and on two occasions. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to people facing difficulties. Hughes will be sentenced next week.

Yorkshire, aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, lost to Surrey in a match. After a promising start with Dominic Sibley and Kumar Sangakkara scoring quickly, Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Despite Matthew Waite's 3-48, Yorkshire were left to rue dropping Davies and Rory Burns. After losing Adam Lyth early, Yorkshire were well-placed at 75-2, but Meaker turned the game with his wickets. Surrey's fast bowler Stuart Meaker (3-61) turned the game on its head by ripping out Bairstow, Ballance, and Jack Leaning. Despite Bresnan and Waite's best efforts, Surrey won by 27 runs, with Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressing disappointment.

The passage describes a 56ft trawler that was 6 miles west of South Stack when its onboard pump failed to handle the influx of water. The crew then contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. The Holyhead coastguards and the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the vessel and towing it to Holyhead.

24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, Muir, will not be joining the Scotland team at the Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir is focused on completing her final year of studies and believes she has at least two or three more Olympics in her future. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir's outdoor personal best in the 5,000m is 14 minutes 52.07 seconds, achieved in London.

The passage discusses Liverpool's current situation in the Premier League, their title challenge, and the impact of Steven Gerrard's slip that led to Chelsea winning last season. Liverpool overachieved last season, raising expectations unrealistically, and have lost key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge. The team is struggling to score goals, with Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini as their main frontmen. They are also struggling defensively, with set-piece defense and leadership being major issues. The author, Robbie Savage, believes that Liverpool will struggle against Chelsea due to their superior quality. Despite this, Savage still sees Gerrard as an important player for Liverpool and believes he will continue to play for the team.

The Â£45m facility, to be built in Kilmarnock, will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council plans to name it after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer from Kilmarnock who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, who became an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University, gained fame with his first novel and became known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir". He wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works. McIlvanney was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He died in Glasgow on 5 December. The council leader expressed delight at the opportunity to preserve McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock.

The passage discusses an evacuation near a swimming pool in Gourock, Scotland, due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is believed to be a British one from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets and nearby residents were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. A 500m exclusion zone was also established. Small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services. The mine was moved to a safer place before being dealt with due to its deterioration and the uncertainty of its explosive material content. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the procedures.

The passage discusses the funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have been excluded from the funding. Cycling, which contributed 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding cut by £4m to £25.98m. Badminton, which was set to win a medal in Rio, has had its funding removed, causing concern from its executives. Judo, which also had one bronze medal, has had its funding slightly increased. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The government has confirmed its commitment to Tokyo 2020. UK Sport's approach to elite sport has been successful in previous Olympics, and the ambition to win more medals in Tokyo is a bold one. Basketball, handball, and volleyball have expressed concern that UK Sport has no

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's designated conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The council voted seven to three in favor of the development, citing its potential to boost tourism. The new building will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. Despite 246 letters of support, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, arguing that the altered buildings still retain historic character. English Heritage also opposed the project due to its scale.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was fatally attacked in Brecon while off-duty. Jake Vallely, 24, has been charged with manslaughter. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of involvement. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar after Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge. Vallely was sentenced on 8 December. The victim's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead, and expressed the "unbearable pain" of losing him.

Andrew Travers resigned from his position as Barnet Council's chief executive following an error that led to voters being turned away from 155 polling stations due to their names not being on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The investigation will conclude by the end of May and will examine the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead won the match 2-1 against Wrexham. The first half was disappointing for Gateshead, but they improved in the second half. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick, and Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with another impressive set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading Craig Baxter's cross into the net. Wrexham had several chances but couldn't convert them into goals. The match ended with Gateshead winning 2-1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic welfare of people aged 60 and above. Norway tops the list, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank last.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe, with a target of providing every school with a connection. The project requires building a large constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, which could eventually grow to over 2,000. To achieve this, Airbus is implementing new manufacturing methods similar to those used in car and plane factories, aiming for a production cost of less than a million dollars per unit. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more in a soon-to-open factory complex in Florida. The project requires a significant launch campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked to launch clusters of satellites into orbit. The constellation is expected to be fully operational by the middle of the decade, with just under 300 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020, over 600 by the middle of the decade, and more than 800 by the end of the decade. OneWeb is not the only company planning a mega-constellation, but it has raised

The UK government's recent spending review has imposed "unprecedented pressure" on Scottish public expenditure, with the Scottish government arguing that cuts since 2010 and the latest spending review will result in a 12.5% reduction in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. The Scottish government claims that £1bn of cuts still need to be made between now and 2020. The Scottish government, led by Finance Secretary Derek Swinney, is determined to defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service from austerity measures. The UK government's Scotland Office responds that the Scottish government will have £390m more spending available next year, and that the UK economy provides a better deal for Scotland than the constitutional alternative favored by the Scottish government. The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when accessing suitable toilet facilities in public places. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which are larger and have additional features to meet the needs of people who use them. Currently, there are over 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners argue that they should be made compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities. The passage also mentions the psychological impact of not having access to appropriate toilet facilities on the whole family. While there are some positive examples of businesses installing Changing Places toilets, such as Arsenal Football Club, there are also logistical and financial barriers to installation. The passage concludes by emphasizing the importance of making toilet facilities accessible to all customers.

A group of Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the fast-food giant forces its Italian franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's denies these claims, stating that they share risks and rewards with their licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint, which alleges that McDonald's abuses its dominant market position, hurting franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission and can launch an investigation if the allegations are found to be valid. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and higher lease premises from the company, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The passage is about a 13-year-old boy named Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. He was due for an operation on his appendix at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, but doctors discovered a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The news shocked his family, but they received global support from people all over the world through a social media campaign started by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram and has since gone viral, with over 79,000 people viewing the updates about Josh. A mystery donor paid for a billboard to be erected at Holywood playing fields, and there has been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for Josh.

The UK government has announced a reorganization of military buildings, including the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales. The barracks, which has been in operation since 1805, has been home to troops who fought in various conflicts, including the Zulu war at Rorke's Drift. The closure has been met with criticism from Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies, who has launched a petition against the decision. Davies has expressed concern about the potential impact on the local military tourism industry and unemployment levels. The reorganization will see a specialist light infantry center created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, with Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire, and a storage depot at Sennybridge also set to close. The ministry has stated that the restructuring is necessary, but has not provided specific details on the potential impact on jobs or the military tourism industry.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. The industry has been marginalized in wider Brexit negotiations due to its low GDP contribution and employment figures. However, many in the industry argue that Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. The UK's fishing industry is heavily reliant on EU member states for market access, and Brexit may involve trade-offs, such as EU member states demanding more access to UK waters in return for continued rights to sell fish to the European market with zero tariffs. The report suggests that many elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas continue to be based on scientific advice. The report also highlights the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if Britain leaves the EU. The passage discusses the revelations made by Edward Snowden regarding the US National Security Agency's (NSA) mass surveillance activities. The NSA has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals. They also have a relationship with nine major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple, which have denied involvement. The NSA's activities are justified as a means to keep Americans secure, but critics argue that the secrecy surrounding these operations raises concerns about privacy and national security. The passage also mentions the US Patriot Act of 2001, which gave American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US. The existence of Prism, a program reportedly established in 2007, has raised concerns about global surveillance and privacy. The EU Justice Commission has expressed concern about the consequences of Prism for EU citizens. Snowden, the source of the leaked documents, acted due to concerns about privacy and the extent of US surveillance.

The venture, OpenAI, is backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, and Indian tech giant Infosys. It aims to conduct AI research free from financial obligations, focusing on a "positive human impact". Scientists warn that AI could pose a threat to humanity, with Musk and Hawking expressing concerns. However, other experts disagree, stating the risk is remote. OpenAI's goal is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, unconstrained by financial returns. They aim for AI to be an extension of human wills, distributed broadly and safely. Only a small fraction of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

Lance Corporal Ben Parkinson, based in Doncaster, was severely injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He has been carrying the Olympic torch since 26 June, receiving thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but can only accept a limited number due to the site's restrictions. Despite a brain injury that affected his speech, he walked nearly half an hour with the torch, supported by an assistant. Parkinson is known for his determination and sense of humor, spending 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and raising money for military charities. His mother, Diane, has received over 5,000 friend requests and thousands of messages of support. Facebook advised Parkinson to create a page or use subscribe to handle the increased traffic. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame during its journey to the Olympic Games opening ceremony in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, with 46.2 million people living in poverty, a figure that remained unchanged after three years of increases. Real median income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010.

The passage discusses Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer from Somerset who moved to Lancashire (the Red Rose) in 2013. He has signed a new deal with the club until 2019. Buttler is known for his short-format specialization and has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers in the game, stating that Buttler's presence in the T20 Blast final at Edgbaston was a factor in their win. Buttler, who is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The four decommissioned Type 22 frigates - HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall - are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest in acquiring these ships, with final bids due in late February and March. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the country's ship recycling capabilities. Penny Mordaunt, the Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, advocates for preserving at least one frigate as a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. No proposals to preserve the ships as museums have been submitted. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with advanced weapons systems. They were known for their excellent command and control facilities, making them ideal flagships on deployments. Last year,

Fiji, a former British colony, has experienced racial and political tensions since 1987, leading to several coups and international isolation. The 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew the Indian-dominated coalition, resulting in a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian supremacy that was later withdrawn. The 2000 coup, led by businessman George Speight, held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and cabinet hostage for weeks, causing significant economic and reputational damage. The 2006 military takeover was the fourth coup in 20 years, and Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 for lack of progress towards democracy. The government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and re-admission to the Commonwealth.
