Syria has been accused of using barrel bombs in Aleppo, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reporting 246 deaths in the last five days. The Syrian government denies this and claims it is defending against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government has also been accused of missing a deadline to hand over its chemical weapons, with only 4% of the stockpile having left the country so far. The US and Russia have set deadlines for the complete transfer and destruction of Syria's chemical weapons by 1 March and the end of June respectively. The Syrian government has stated it is committed to all its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The 2014 Booker Prize shortlist includes Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others," a novel set in 1960s Calcutta, as the 5/2 favorite. The prize is open to all English-writing authors, regardless of nationality. The shortlist also features Howard Jacobson's "J," Ali Smith's "How To Be Both," Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." Jacobson, a former Booker winner, is nominated for his futuristic love story "J." The novel explores a world where the past is not spoken about and is shrouded in suspicion. Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others" begins in Calcutta in 1967, focusing on the secrets and rivalries within a family against a backdrop of political activism. The other shortlisted authors are Inverness-born Smith, American Ferris, and Australian Flanagan. Fow

The man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide whether to grant or dismiss the appeal. The man has young children and his spouse is also in the public eye. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by the man, but he argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The man had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. They had a text message exchange in December 2011 discussing a "three-way" with AB's partner, CD, and met for a three-way sexual encounter. The man approached the Sun on Sunday with the story, but a High Court judge initially refused to impose an injunction. The man appealed and two appeal court judges ruled in his favour, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. News Group Newspapers, publishers of the Sun on Sunday,

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, was bought in August 2022 for £345.5m. The new owners, Crown Estates, plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, stated that the new owners have met with the council to clarify "potential planning questions". The council aims to enhance the view of Fosse Park from the city, currently dominated by backs of sheds. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, mentioned that they plan to address parking and congestion issues, as well as improve the quality of common areas and facilities to make Fosse Park a better location.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, but Disney is reviewing its content. The film was initially due for release in Malaysia on Thursday, but a new release date has not been announced. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification". Local cinema chains are offering refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance. The decision to review the film courted criticism from netizens.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people in Southampton are required to obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost up to £1,000 but carries a maximum fine of £20,000. Despite this, many landlords are deterred due to the cost. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants often express concerns about eviction and living in poorly maintained properties due to the lack of affordable housing. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance. The licensing regime applies to properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett.

Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin, leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil respectively, are seeking to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil, with 44 seats, wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael, with 50 seats, sees a role for them. A commission to consider Irish Water's future is being considered. No party has been able to form a majority government since the last election, with TDs failing to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, experienced a fire that quickly got out of control. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital by helicopter. The fire started on one of the car decks around 27km from Mallorca. The cause of the fire is unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to help. The rescued passengers were taken to the Puglia ferry and expected to arrive in Palma de Mallorca in a few hours. Psychologists were deployed to provide counseling. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire. The ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time. The captain initially did not believe an evacuation was necessary but ordered one due to the intense fire.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs discovered individuals, including students, who voted twice, a criminal offence. The Commission suggested joining individual electoral registers run by councils to identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% actually voting, the highest turnout since 1997. There was a surge in applications to register to vote after Theresa May called the snap poll on 18 April, with 2.9 million applications received. Concerns about duplicate applications persist due to the lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The Commission estimated that 30% to 70% of applications may be duplicates, causing administration and financial burdens. The Commission recommended clearer information on registration sites, including a verification function, and urgent action to address the issue. Despite efforts to discourage re-registration, many people submitted another application due to the ease of online registration. The Commission emphasized

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL star and University of Nebraska player, is believed to have committed suicide. In the 1990s, he played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers but was plagued by legal issues and anger problems. He was sent to prison for assault and served a long term for another assault conviction. Phillips was accused of killing his cellmate and was placed in a cell alone. A judge found enough evidence to try him in the death of Damion Soward. The cause of Phillips' suicide is unknown. His coach at Nebraska described him as intelligent and having good qualities but struggling with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century, was promoted to lance corporal and awarded an honor by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, receives payment for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. He has also assisted in switching on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Summary:

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League semi-first leg, with goals from Dejan Lovren, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho. The match was marked by Liverpool's resilience and determination, overcoming a 2-0 deficit to turn the game around. Jurgen Klopp's impact on the team was evident, with his inspiring words and the team's ability to turn doubts into belief. The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with the fans playing a significant role in the team's performance. Liverpool's next challenge will be to overcome Sevilla in the semi-finals, with the Europa League final and a potential return to the Champions League also within reach. Klopp has emphasized the importance of winning and respecting the 'This Is Anfield' sign before touching it.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee held a meeting in London where the UK government committed to regular monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to share analysis and updates on negotiations with Brussels. The UK government aims to work together with the devolved administrations to get the best deal for the UK. However, the Scottish government's representative, Mr. Russell, expressed concern about the lack of clarity from the UK government on its strategic intentions regarding EU market access and the customs union. He emphasized the importance of membership in the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes the High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government intends to oppose this in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The passage discusses a study on 13 cloned sheep, including Dolly the sheep, which were cloned from the same adult ewe. These sheep are among the most closely monitored and studied animals in the world, with the fate of the science of cloning depending on their health and aging. The cloning process involves extracting DNA from an adult animal's fully differentiated cell, raising concerns about transferring "age-memory" to the next generation. This could make cloned animals appear older and develop diseases associated with aging at a younger age. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old due to a virus and osteoarthritis, which raised concerns about premature aging. The study involved putting the dollies through extensive tests and assessments, including joint X-rays and fMRI scans, to determine if cloned animals have higher rates of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week. Currently, the dollies appear to be in good health,

Summary:

- Unbeaten favourite, trained by John Gosden, won a race after walking the course. She beat the second-placed horse, Vintage Folly, by a length and three-quarters.
- The horse will not run in the Oaks at Epsom, instead going to Chantilly. Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Oaks.
- Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas, with Jim Crowley's mount winning comfortably from Magical Memory in second, and Comicas third.
- Shutter Speed, who last ran at Newbury and beat Enable into third, won her fifth Musidora race for Gosden and Dettori. Dettori commented that the ground was very soft and hard work for the horse.
- Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding whether to run in the Derby trial.
- BBC Sport horse racing correspondent

The pound has been experiencing volatility, initially slipping against the dollar and euro but then recovering and falling again. It has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis, according to the "volatility index". The Leave campaign argues that the pound is retreating to March levels. Two recent polls show the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain has fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. The pound has lost more than 2% in two sessions, and Asian stock markets have also reacted negatively due to concerns about the economic impact of leaving the EU. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller.

The Iron are currently in sixth place in the National League, just one point outside the play-offs. They lost to Barrow, who have won nine consecutive league games, but manager Cowley remains positive. He acknowledges the team's impressive performance so far, despite being a part-time team, and expresses determination to enjoy and embrace their toughest challenge yet.

The passage discusses the proposed shift in planning responsibilities from the Planning Service, an agency under Stormont's environment department, to local councils in Northern Ireland. This change is expected to take effect from April 2015, aiming to democratize the planning system by allowing elected politicians to make planning decisions. However, there are concerns about the potential for discrimination and close relationships between developers and political parties, which could lead to a laissez-faire system. To ensure fairness and transparency, a strict code of conduct will need to be enforced, and there is a call for increased public knowledge of political party donations, particularly in light of the potential financial consequences for developers and objectors. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to implement measures to shed more light on political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg, which had to be amputated. The cat survived and is now learning to walk again. The incident has raised concerns about the lack of licensing for air weapons in Scotland, with a majority of respondents opposing the proposed scheme in a 2021 consultation. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool has signed Belgian international Christian Benteke on a long-term contract for an undisclosed fee, triggering a release clause in his contract. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, was previously signed by Liverpool for £7m in 2012. The club has struggled for goals in recent seasons, finishing sixth in the Premier League last season. Benteke's signing is aimed at reviving Liverpool's attack, along with other new signings Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, Danny Ings, and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield, while former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is excited about the addition of Benteke's "massive presence" up front.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly used in schools (68% in primary and 69% in secondary), there's no clear evidence of improved academic results. The rapid growth of tablet use is also seen at home. The study reported that 9% of schools have individual tablets for every pupil, with academy schools showing the highest use. The number of tablets in schools is expected to rise from 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While it's challenging to isolate the impact of technology on academic results, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers, like tablets, are particularly useful for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The study also highlighted that tablets are part of everyday life for young people, with many describing themselves as "internet addicts" and using devices for social media or watching videos before bed.

The Museum of Liverpool's exhibition, 'Growing Up in the City', features 25 evocative photographs that depict the life of children in the city over more than 100 years. The images, spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, provide a snapshot of childhood and a social history of Liverpool. They show children at play, special occasions, and also illustrate the work of youngsters. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes a portrait of the Rollo family from 1887 and a 1900 image of a young maid from a well-to-do Liverpool family. The exhibition aims to show both the good and bad experiences of childhood.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow and joined their rivals in the National League. He could potentially face his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been signed by Barrow from Sligo Rovers. He was recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams and is subject to international clearance. Barrow is currently in the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia, a poor South American country, that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including 30 years in jail for child homicide. The law was approved by Congress and signed into law by the Vice-President, despite the President being unavailable due to travel. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia work to support their families, often in hazardous conditions. The law aims to eradicate extreme poverty and is not in line with international conventions on child labor, but the International Labour Organization is studying its compliance.

50-year-old actress O'Donnell fell ill at home, experiencing sudden nausea, aches, and chest pain. She looked up symptoms online, found "women's heart attack symptoms," and took aspirin. The next day, she visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent after finding a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell had a "widow maker" heart attack, a type of attack known for its severity. She did not call emergency services but later warned women to recognize heart attack symptoms and call 911. The Rosie Show, where she hosted, was cancelled due to low ratings.

16-year-old Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was stabbed to death at a well-organized party in Kenton, Kent, on Saturday night. He was not involved in an initial altercation with a group of youths but was later targeted and stabbed in an alleyway. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A man aged 21 has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed. A third boy aged 14 is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses a reorganization of patient diagnosis by GPs and specialists in Wales, inspired by Denmark's improved cancer diagnosis system. The issue was long waiting times for patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms, which led to poor cancer survival statistics in Denmark. The new model in Denmark has three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms GPs can't diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have resulted in better organization, reduced waiting times, and improved survival rates in Denmark. The Welsh Cancer Network's medical director, Dr. Tom Crosby, has been impressed with Denmark's collaboration between GPs and specialists to achieve better diagnoses.

31 March 2014: Powys Council to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest or breaching estate agents, replacing the disbanded OFT. Powys to receive £170,000 annually for the service. Complaints will still go to local authorities' trading standards, referring breached cases to Powys. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, aiming to demonstrate Powys' capacity for external contracts.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshuffle the healthcare workforce, with nurses potentially taking on more tasks due to doctor and pharmacist shortages. The Nuffield Trust found examples of nurses filling in for doctors and GPs. Unions caution against this as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for good quality training for doctors and adequate funding for training courses. The report highlights the changing nature of care, with more focus on long-term conditions, and the need for more staff to support doctors.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First said it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal, and they hope to have a full service running by the evening commute. The police and staff worked together to manage the situation and recovery.

The NRW estimates that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout will die annually due to the tidal lagoon, but TLP disputes these figures, claiming they have no clear scientific basis. TLP argues that NRW's figures are based on "what if" scenarios and lack evidence. They present their own computer modeling estimating a "worst case scenario" of 2% impact on all fish species. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary is seeking clarity on the UK's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and asserts that their figures are based on the best available evidence after consulting with the developer and independent experts.

The passage discusses the announcement of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, led by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This body aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move is significant as Northern Ireland's agri-food industry employs almost 100,000 people in sectors like farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The new body will address the need for better coordination of current marketing activities, as indicated by industry representatives. However, it may have implications for other organizations, including the Agriculture Minister's department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees, including 40,000 in Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1, particularly those from the island of Ireland. The public is invited to participate in planting the trees, with the charity providing saplings and encouraging them to wear welly boots. The project aims to create a place for wildlife to thrive and for people to walk, relax, and reflect.

Hilary, a crime novelist, won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival. The award-winning book, "Someone Else's Skin", is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. The book was praised for its emotionally exhausting and powerful story, as well as its finely written and tightly written plot. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky was recognized for her impact on female writers and her role in establishing Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers around the world.

Worcestershire CCC, led by director of cricket Steve Rhodes, aims to have left-arm batsman and spinner Mitch Santner back in their squad for the 2017 season. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, was unfortunate to break his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, which hindered their hopes of qualifying for the tournament. Santner enjoyed his time at Worcestershire with the team and is looking forward to making up for lost time in the 2017 season. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the entire 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was in Ukraine at the time, and Pring's family believes he was murdered. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Pring, tried to claim his assets soon after his death. The couple met online in 2006 and married in 2007. Pring was hit by a car with no lights, speeding at 75mph, and witnesses described the killing as a deliberate act. The Ukrainian police closed the case initially but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011. Ziuzina sold Pring's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate and was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. The coroner recorded

Charlie Fearns, a 12-year-old boy from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle, America for an experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital, as the UK does not have this treatment available. Charlie has been battling illness since the age of three and had a third relapse in April, leaving no other treatment options in the UK. The first T-Cell transplant did not work, leaving the family heartbroken. However, an anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, which was confirmed via email from the hospital on Wednesday. The treatment will start as soon as possible, and the family expects to find out the date next week.

Apple has been accused of allowing third-party software to steal intimate photos from celebrities' iCloud accounts. To prevent this, Apple is introducing a two-step verification system that requires an extra step after typing the username and password, a four-digit code texted to a trusted mobile number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app, and a 14-character recovery key for account access. This system was not previously in place, allowing attackers to download a complete back-up of data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The software's owner, Vladimir Katalov, has acknowledged that Apple's changes make his program ineffective. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves revealed that the terms of a deal, where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Old Boys, are still being finalized. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity winner, will become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points behind a play-off spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has committed to investing £10,000 a week. Billericay has recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who also chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee plans to meet with Mr. Ashley at the company's base in Shirebrook, with the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage being key issues. The committee has committed to transparency and will meet in public at Westminster. Sports Direct has not yet agreed to the offered dates for the meeting, and if they fail to respond, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. The company had previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The report, "Putin. War," was intended to be written by a group led by Ilya Yashin, but was never completed. It primarily focuses on the Russian-language report, titled "Putin. War," which is based on facts that have been reported in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in 2014 and conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine. The report alleges that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, with Russian soldiers and equipment playing a decisive role in securing victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report also presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit that they were directed by Russian generals in the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report's authors claim that Russian spending on the conflict is estimated at 53 billion roubles (Â£665m; $1bn). The opposition plans to extend the initial print run of only 2,000

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to publish the Article 50 letter, which includes the UK's intention to return powers to the devolved administrations. The Welsh First Minister, Carwyn Jones, expressed frustration that he hadn't seen the letter before it was published and that the devolved administrations were not consulted in its drafting. The UK government aims to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but the Welsh Secretary, Alun Cairns, defended the government's actions, stating that the Prime Minister has been in Wales three times in the last six weeks and that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. The letter mentions Wales and the expectation is that the outcome of the process will be a significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration. However, the specific powers that the UK government wants to see devolved to Wales is still a mystery.

Two cars were damaged in a incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page reported that police were attacked while carrying out duties and appealed to parents to keep track of their children's whereabouts.

Mr. Charney, co-founder of American Apparel, was removed from his position due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. He was accused of misconduct, including sending inappropriate emails to female employees and using racially derogatory language. These actions led to his defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The board of directors stated they would not hire him due to the risks involved. American Apparel recently obtained a restraining order to prevent him from making negative statements about the company in the press and from attempting to remove board members.

The British basketball team, GB, will face Greece in a game that will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The match took place in Patras, Greece, where Greece won with a score of 92-64. Three Greek players will not be present, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game will be played at the Copper Box in Stratford, London, and is GB's only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017 in September. After this game, GB will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland as their last warm-up before EuroBasket. The game will start at 17:30 and end at 19:30 BST.

The passage discusses the introduction of the iPhone by Apple in 2007, which marked a significant shift in the use of mobile phones from just making calls to multifunctional devices. The author, initially denied an interview with Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller, was later given a chance to see the iPhone before it was launched. The iPhone's innovative user interface and features, such as the ability to capture and share high-quality photos, revolutionized the way people used their mobile devices. The author reflects on how the iPhone changed the way people thought about photography and other activities, and how it paved the way for future innovations in mobile technology, such as artificial intelligence.

The RSPCA has confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have ingested a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen being the most recent victim, who died on Monday. The cause of the poisonings is unclear, whether accidental or deliberate. In the past seven days, three other cats have died, and another two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, found the cat behind the sofa, foaming from the mouth and trying to vomit. The cat was taken to the vet, where it was confirmed that Meereen had consumed antifreeze and died three days later. The RSPCA is appealing for residents to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially with the increased use of antifreeze in cars during this time of year.

The passage discusses the impending third bailout for Greece, which is being negotiated by the Syriza government. Despite the austerity and liberalization measures that will be implemented, Greece's resorts are thriving, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. The Greek population is not protesting against the announced VAT increases and pension cuts, but there is curiosity about why the government is rushing to agree to these terms. The passage suggests that Greece's near-death experience in July has turned Syriza into supporters of TINA ("there is no alternative"), and Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end austerity. The new bailout will only be successful if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead, and creditors need to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainable debts.

The passage discusses the return of actor Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, for Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Barbara, who played Peggy Mitchell, announced her character's death due to cancer, which will be shown in emotional scenes in the spring. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, will return to bring the Mitchell family together for the last time with Peggy. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character in EastEnders, will be reunited with his brother Phil and old loves before Peggy's death. The return of Kemp and the emotional storyline are expected to be classic EastEnders episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, a Northumbria Police officer, fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October after stalking her. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed by the police about her death and immediately suspected Dhillon. They had tried to reassure Alice on the phone two days before, but when her daughter informed them of Dhillon's obsession and the danger he posed, they realized the severity of the situation. Dhillon denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to honor Alice's memory.

The Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, UK, has faced a series of developments. The French firm EDF, financing most of the £18bn project, approved the funding at a board meeting, with contracts to be signed on Friday. However, Business Secretary Greg Clark has said the government will "consider carefully" before backing it. EDF chief executive Vincent de Rivaz cancelled a trip to Hinkley Point following Mr Clark's comments. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign ownership, with one third of the £18bn cost being provided by Chinese investors. The government launched a further review of the project, causing EDF executives to be taken off guard. The project, expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement, has faced financial risks for EDF, which has had to raise money from its owners. Environmentalists are also concerned about the plan, with Greenpeace executive director John Sauven stating that the Hinkley deal became too big to fail for British and French politici

The newly designed divorce form in England and Wales, used for applying for a divorce, includes a question asking for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with. This addition has raised concerns among family lawyers, who argue that involving a third party adds conflict and complexity to the process. The Ministry of Justice has stated that there is no obligation to name people, but lawyers like Margaret Heathcote, vice-chairwoman of family law group Resolution, believe that it increases conflict and is not necessary. The older version of the form left a space for so-called "co-respondents" to be named, but the new form flatly asks for the name, making it an invitation that most broken hearts may not be able to resist. If the person is named, they become part of the court case, and may be sent copies of the paperwork and given a chance to respond. According to the latest statistics, adultery was the reason for 12,148 of the 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 201

Summary:

- Britain is a significant importer of wood, with Wales being a major contributor to the timber industry.
- Conifer forests, established for half a century, have been crucial for the timber industry but are being replaced due to environmental policies.
- At least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted.
- The forestry industry is worth over £450m to the Welsh economy, but it faces conflicts with environmental policy, which favors native, broadleaf species and better access for walkers and bike riders.
- The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, promoting the Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales forestry strategy.
- Confor, representing 200 Welsh businesses, believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as "sexier" than commercial forestry and that the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas.

A boy was severely injured in a incident in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, on Bank Street around 16:40. He was rushed to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with serious injuries.

The Arctic Convoys were a series of military operations during World War II, where British merchant vessels supplied the Soviet Union with essential supplies. These convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy aimed to honor the veterans with the Medal of Ushakov, but the Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to its rules. However, the British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012, and the Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" in 2013, allowing the veterans to receive the Russian accolade during President Vladimir Putin's visit to London.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in offenders starting their work and many were let off if they didn't attend. In one case, an offender had completed only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations. Unpaid work, or "community payback", can range from 40 to 300 hours for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the number of offenders turned away from work and creating objectives that match the offender's circumstances. The chief inspector of probation, Paul Wilson, criticized the current system, stating that unpaid work is often viewed as a punishment rather than rehabilitation. The Ministry of Justice wants "much more effective rehabilitation" and is taking action on the report's recommendations.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding comedian Russell Brand, who is accused of hypocrisy for advocating for economic and political revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury home. Brand's wealth and lifestyle have been criticized, particularly when he was seen outside the prime minister's Downing Street home supporting a campaign against gentrification. He was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter, which led to an argument. Brand has been condemned as a hypocrite before and has acknowledged his wealth and fame, but argues that he is committed to personal change and systemic economic reform. He believes that inequality is a real problem that needs to be addressed and that his wealth and fame have been overhyped.

The passage is about Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race, despite being vilified by the scientific community. He is known for his wealth and use of luxury items, but his work in human genomics has significantly accelerated the process. After the human genome publication, Venter turned to creating a synthetic life form, which he achieved in 2010 with the help of scientists at the J Craig Venter Institute. Venter's journey to becoming a scientist was influenced by his experiences in Vietnam, where he witnessed the importance of time and the need for urgency in medical care. He excelled in research during his medical training and realized the importance of decoding genes in the early days of molecular biology. Venter's breakthrough came when he realized that cells already use active parts of the DNA blueprint, allowing him to churn out gene sequences at unprecedented rates. His success was met with criticism and failure to secure further public research funding, leading him to set up a private research institute and later a commercial company, C

The passage discusses a survey of about 1,000 parents in England regarding their children's school lunches. Key findings include:

- Four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home.
- Half of parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home.
- The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular.
- England's School Food Trust commissioned the research after a survey by Mumsnet suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else.
- The Trust chairman, Rob Rees, emphasized the potential of school meals to encourage children to try new foods and increase the variety of their diet.
- Mumsnet co-founder, Carrie Longton, noted that school meals can provide a positive environment for children to try new foods and fit in with their peers.
- School meals

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker playing for Juventus, joined the Italian club in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. He had an option for Real to buy him back with a fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata has scored three times for Spain in Euro 2016 and scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in two Champions League finals, having appeared as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. Morata, who stands at 6ft 3in, came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, a 30-year-old player, rejoined Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5m. He had previously played for Preston North End and Notts County. However, he was released in May and has been without a team since then. In his second spell at Forest, he made 51 appearances.

Tesco, the UK's third-largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. The deal includes transferring around 4,000 employees to the new business and loaning it Â£80m. Fresh & Easy, operating in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since 2007. Tesco will incur Â£150m in disposal costs, but this includes a loan that may be repaid. If Yucaipa succeeds and the business becomes profitable, Tesco can buy a stake. This move comes after Tesco reported its first annual profit drop in 20 years.

The passage is about a martial artist who faced racial abuse but overcame it. He initially considered representing France but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. For those interested in martial arts, there's a special guide available.

The passage discusses the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past four decades. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the glaciers covered about 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s, this had decreased to around 275 sq km. The study, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess the roughly 600 glaciers in the region. Manual inspection was used to verify satellite data due to issues with debris cover and shadows. The glacial coverage has decreased by about 26% over the last 40 years, with the greatest losses in the southern sectors. The northern region, including the biggest French glacier - La Mer de Glace, has seen a decrease in area from 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to over 30 sq km today. Efforts to assess and monitor gl

Scotland, led by player Kim Evans, is aiming to secure their place in the 2023 Women's World Cup by winning their remaining two qualifiers. They have already won all five qualifiers and will face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with a victory securing their spot. Evans, who has played in Germany with Turbine Potsdam, believes having more players in top leagues like Germany benefits the national team. Iceland, ranked 20th in the world, is also unbeaten and the outcome of the Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will decide who tops the group. Evans is one of 12 players in the current 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England on harassment allegations from a woman in south London. The complaint, made over a two-year period, involved tweets from his Wings Over Scotland blog. Campbell was released on bail and accused the media of spreading innuendo. He insisted the tweets were not threatening and all are still publicly visible.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has suggested replacing Skegness's mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a modern animal-friendly version, proposing a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908, was meant to encourage seaside breaks to Skegness and has become synonymous with the resort. However, Peta argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of animal cruelty, such as tricking fish into impaling themselves and mutilating sea animals. Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, loves the Jolly Fisherman and doesn't see it as promoting animal cruelty, but Peta's suggestion will be presented to the council for consideration.

Scotland won the match 38-11 against Georgia. The Scottish team led briefly through Vasil Lobzhanidze's early try, but they raced ahead through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before the break. Hamish Watson extended the lead, battling over soon after half-time. Georgia, living off scraps, put over another penalty to make it 24-11 but Hogg's try stretched the lead again. The match was dominated by Scotland, who owned possession and territory and got their reward when a rolling maul, destined for the try-line, was hauled to the floor by the Georgian lock, Kote Mikautadze. Scotland got a penalty try, converted by Laidlaw, and Mikautadze got the sin-bin. Georgia had ambition and luck at its heart, with Hogg's try being a result of a dinked kick over the top and chasing like hell. The match was pr

Widnes Vikings defeated Cas with a score of 38-12. Tries were scored by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White, and Joe Mellor for Widnes. Cas' Paddy Flynn scored two tries, and Larne Patrick and Luke Gale also scored a try each. Despite Castleford's loss, Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti national, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel concluded he was not a continuing significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. After challenging his detention in the US Supreme Court, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane in August 2014. He will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait before potentially returning to Kuwait. Mr Odah is the first inmate to be freed since May 2014, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. The US opened the facility in January 2002 following the 11 September 2001 attacks, and President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was observed with a dawn service in Hyde Park Corner and a parade at the Cenotaph. Thousands attended, including expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians. The services, held at Westminster Abbey and featuring the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia, honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. The Gallipoli landings, a significant event in the campaign, were reflected upon, with descriptions of the enthusiasm, courage, and heroism of the Anzac troops. The event was attended by the Australian high commissioner to the UK, who laid a wreath.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old forward, joined St Mirren on a second spell in July and could make his debut against Alloa. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been a substitute for most of this term. Capped twice for Scotland, Clarkson has made nearly 400 senior appearances and has played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of Alloa. Clarkson is ready to play and aims to help St Mirren win games and push up the table.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Concerns were raised about the new owners not continuing the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite union representative Steve Harley reported that productive talks were held and guarantees were given that all current agreements would be upheld. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, but its members currently have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable state through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing present spare capacity for processing chicken and not just turkeys.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July to address issues and gather feedback. The ferry, a new vessel, has faced problems since its launch on 14 May, including breaking down, running aground, and being suspended due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged while getting on and off. The ferry's launch has caused significant disruption to local businesses, with shopkeeper Angie Booth expressing concern about the impact on her business and others. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors and plans to compensate local businesses for their losses. The council councillor, Ian Ward, acknowledged the teething problems and mentioned that electrical issues have been resolved, and ramp extensions have been authorized to prevent vehicles from scraping the concrete. Groundings were an issue with seamanship, which has been addressed.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK's fishing industry. The industry has been marginalized in wider Brexit negotiations due to its low GDP contribution and employment figures. However, many in the industry argue that Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry, and many fear that if Britain leaves the EU, the CFP framework will fall away, leading to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the industry believe that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, with the potential for fairer shares in catching opportunity and better sustainable fisheries management. The government has stated that leaving the EU is an opportunity to review fisheries management and ensure fair access to quota, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to downloading inappropriate images of young boys between 2004 and 2014. He was subjected to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and removed from his profession's register by the General Teaching Council Scotland. The panel found his conduct fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher, indicating a pattern of behavior that posed a strong likelihood of recurring offending. Geaney was prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street following a blaze on 2 March, which caused train service reductions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, but the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit due to concerns about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The company is still required to remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

Syria has been accused of using barrel bombs in Aleppo, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reporting 246 deaths in the last five days. The Syrian government denies this and claims they are defending against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government also denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, with both sides claiming control. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% of the stockpile having left the country so far. The US and Russia have set deadlines for Syria to complete the transfer and destruction of its chemical weapons. The OPCW has admitted that the process has been slowed down by security concerns.

England won the match with a day to spare at Old Trafford, leveling the series. They scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, making it their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Root also took four catches and claimed a wicket in his only over, helping Pakistan be bowled out for 234 on Monday. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's performance, saying he played beautifully and didn't put a foot wrong. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second, with their spirit broken. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott praised England's performance, citing their quality of batting, discipline, and good bowling. England are in a good position to win the series, while Pak

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She plans to gather experiences from older people, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner aims to highlight good care and show the impact of poor care on older people. However, Care Forum Wales has expressed disappointment that the review panel does not include a provider expert, missing the opportunity for partnership working and sector engagement.

Sheerin, a former Aberdeen midfielder, has been the manager of Arbroath since 2010. He has been appointed as Aberdeen's new player-manager, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, winning a Scotland Under-21 cap. He led Arbroath to their first national trophy, the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser confirmed that Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a thorough process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison was understanding of Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea want to appoint their new boss quickly, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis believes the current squad is good enough to stay up, and new signers are aware of the club's history and the importance of avoiding relegation. He thinks the club has lost some of its identity since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent changes in management and the loss of key players.

The passage is about Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race, despite being vilified by the scientific community. He is known for his wealth and use of luxury items, but his work in human genomics has significantly accelerated the process. After the human genome publication, Venter turned to creating a synthetic life form, which he achieved in 2010 with the help of scientists at the J Craig Venter Institute. Venter's journey to becoming a scientist was not linear; he initially pursued a career in medicine but was inspired by the Vietnam conflict and his medical training to become a researcher. His breakthrough came when he realized that cells already use active parts of the genome naturally, allowing him to churn out gene sequences at unprecedented rates. Venter's efforts to crack the human genetic code in three years with Celera Genomics faced criticism, but both projects published their results in 2001. Venter has since formed the J Craig Venter Institute and continued to pursue

The passage discusses the state of apprenticeships in England, which are criticized for being low-quality and too short compared to other European countries. The Sutton Trust warns that thousands of apprenticeships should be created to boost the economy and improve youngsters' job prospects. The Department for Education plans to reform apprenticeships to "drive up standards," but the Association of Colleges suggests preserving some respected level two apprenticeships. The report highlights that only 61,000 new apprenticeship starts were for young people, while in Germany, 570,000 new apprenticeships are for youngsters, with 90% equivalent to A-levels. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, and no more than 10% of apprenticeships should be two-year courses at level two. The report also emphasizes the importance of good apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness.

The British Paralympic cyclist and swimmer, Sarah Storey, won the 2015 Cyclocross World Cup in Nottwil, Switzerland, more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is 37 and targeting Rio de Janeiro 2016 Paralympics, has won 22 medals in six Paralympics, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze. She has won 21 world titles in both cycling and swimming. Storey started her career in swimming, winning 6 medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, a football club, faced financial difficulties leading to their potential expulsion from the Football Conference. The club's debt to football creditors amounted to £148,000. Despite extensions of the payment deadline, Hereford United failed to meet the final deadline on 12 June, leading to their expulsion. The club's owner, Tommy Agombar, took over last week, but the club was already facing debts of approximately £225,000 and over £70,000 to HMRC. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust made an offer to buy the club for £1, but it was not the preferred option. The club's financial situation has been affected by falling attendance and relegation from the Football League in 2012.

The passage provides information about a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who won 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. However, he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The player, who was 30 at the time, wished success to the new manager, Sam Allardyce, and the team.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood was known for his influential work in early-music and his collaborations with leading orchestras worldwide. He made over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Some of his most famous recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He later founded the Early Music Consort of London and served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary

The boy, from Northern Ireland, is being homeschooled due to his family's inability to cope with his special needs. They had to leave his mainstream school and are currently waiting for a place at a special school. However, all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full, and the family has been told an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local school, hoping he can start there soon. The mother is concerned about the over-subscription issue, fearing other families will face similar situations. The Education Authority could not comment on individual cases due to privacy rights but mentioned they are reviewing special school provision and aiming to have places available close to children's residences from 2016.

The Newport County AFC football club is facing a potential takeover of their stadium, Rodney Parade, by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU). The WRU has expressed interest in using the venue as a rugby ground, but Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023 with primacy of fixtures in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by shareholders on May 9. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirmed that both Newport County and Newport Squash Club, which also uses the stadium, are protected under their current agreements. The WRU has signaled their intention to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation zone with two games remaining. Relegation to the National League would be a significant blow for the club and the city of Newport.

The passage is about the author's experiences with the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone in 2014. The author, who had a normal family life before the civil war, was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at 15 and was trained on how to use a gun and initiated into the group. He was subjected to various forms of violence and was forced to kill under the influence of drugs. After escaping the jungle, he was unable to find his relatives and lived alone, but eventually met a preacher named Richard Cole who founded the Lifeline Nehemiah project. Richard encouraged him to continue with his education and taught him about giving back what was invested in him. When the Ebola crisis came to Sierra Leone in 2014, the author and Richard developed a clinic to bring in suspected Ebola cases, which saved many lives. They also educated people about the disease, provided food and other items to those affected, and set up an Ebola treatment unit. The author regrets his past actions but is confident about

80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood pottery firm were saved from auction due to a successful public fundraising campaign led by The Art Fund. The collection, which includes items from the Wedgwood Museum's inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill, will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was made possible by the goodwill and determination shown during negotiations, and the collection was at risk of being sold and scattered globally had the money not been raised. The collection is significant for Britain's cultural development and national identity.

Dan Groves revealed that the terms of a deal, where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Old Boys, are still being finalized. Wright is expected to become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points away from a play-off place. Wright, a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, played for several non-league clubs. Billericay was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed comfort in investing £10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Blackpool scored first with a pinpoint chip from Nathan Delfouneso in the 12th minute. Colchester United equalized from a corner in the 45th minute, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring. Blackpool had a chance to regain the lead but Sam Slocombe saved a close-range effort from George Elokobi. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. Blackpool had several missed opportunities to score, including a header from Jamille Matt and a shot from Colin Daniel. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The passage discusses the proposed development of the disused Fawley power station in Southampton Water, UK. The project aims to transform the site into a "merchant city" with a petal-shaped glass structure as its centerpiece, featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired power station with a 198-meter-high chimney that dominated the Solent skyline. The site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, and they plan to build a £1bn development with an application for outline planning permission due later this year, with construction starting in 2018. The chimney is considered a significant infrastructure element and will be preserved in the new development.

The British cycling team had mixed results at the Hong Kong championships. Elinor Barker won silver in the women's scratch race, and Laura Latham won bronze in the same event after a close finish with Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Lucass Liss of Germany. In the men's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and did not make the bronze-medal ride. Joanna Rowsell Shand commended the young team for their performance, noting their youth and potential. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medalist in the women's sprint, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint event.

The passage discusses the return of actor Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, for Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, agreed to return for Barbara's final scenes. Barbara, who played Peggy Mitchell, announced she would be killed off, and her character reappeared to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned. Peggy died from the disease in emotional scenes to be aired in the spring. Kemp will return to bring the Mitchell family together for Peggy's last moments with her sons. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character in EastEnders, will be reunited with his brother and old loves for Peggy's final moments.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Liverpool defeated second-placed Tottenham Hotspur 2-0. Pochettino criticized Spurs' lack of desire to win, stating that such performances make it difficult to challenge for the Premier League. Spurs have won just twice away from home since September, with recent defeats at Chelsea, Manchester United, Arsenal, and Manchester City. Danny Murphy, a former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder, praised Liverpool's performance and criticized Spurs' change in formation and mindset when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorship posts in the recent Nigerian elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has been in power since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP also lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on 29 May. The APC made historic gains, particularly in the north and south-west, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall, they were more peaceful than previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader due to its 16-year rule and widespread allegations of corruption and failure to end an Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, is offering an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to access online information from site signs and posters, view videos and band interviews on phones and tablets, and interact with the festival globally. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, mentioned that this addition enhances the visitor experience and enables global interaction with the festival's atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. The head teacher of one of the Trojan Horse schools, Oldknow Academy, revealed that parents tried to undermine her authority and descended on the school during an Ofsted inspection. Five schools, including Park View and Oldknow, were rated inadequate and are being targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover. The Department for Education will install a temporary governing board for Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures. Education minister Lord Nash criticized the trusts for failing to promote spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw stated that a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip in Birmingham schools, with a number of head teachers reporting an organized campaign to target certain schools to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. The report into Park View School found that the academy's work to keep

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 due to a build-up of fluid in his brain caused by swollen optic discs, which were not detected during a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The eye specialist, Honey Rose, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter for failing to detect and refer Vinnie for further investigation. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable and that Rose's conduct fell below the expected standards of a competent optometrist. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man, was found guilty of various sexual offenses. He set up meetings between a woman and a man he found on an adult website, filmed their encounters, and sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was also convicted of coercing the woman into sexual activity and intercourse with the man between September 2013 and September 2014, and of intentionally showing sexual images to the woman's sister and father on December 25, 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and sentenced to a term reflecting society's abhorrence at such conduct. He was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in their T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson scoring 56, Gary Wilson 41 no, and William Porterfield 39. However, this was not enough as Afghanistan reached 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari 56 and Mohammad Shahzad 47. Ireland suffered an early blow with Paul Stirling dismissed for a duck. Afghanistan's Amir Hamza took 2 wickets. The loss of Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was another setback for Ireland. They will meet Afghanistan again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with additional fees totaling £106.8m, making the total cost £155.4m. The club denies any tax-related crime and has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13.55m to defend its reputation. The transfer has been under investigation due to allegations of misappropriation of funds by the former president, Sandro Rosell, who resigned last month. A judge in Spain has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue the investigation. Neymar has scored 14 goals in total for Barcelona this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found murdered on Koh Tao on 15 September. Metropolitan Police officers, including two Burmese suspects, are working together on the investigation. The UK detectives will compile a report and update the families of the victims. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are accused of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office has raised concerns about the police investigation, including DNA sample verification and allegations of mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with DNA matching the suspects.

Scotland, led by player Kim Evans, is aiming to reach the finals of the upcoming Netherlands tournament. They have won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Iceland, ranked 20th in the world, is also unbeaten and the outcome of the match will decide the group's top spot. Scotland is in pole position to qualify automatically, with the best six runners-up also securing a spot. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, recently won the Bundesliga and has experience playing in top leagues. She believes having more players in top leagues benefits the national team as they close in on a first major finals.

The passage discusses a security issue where third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple has introduced a two-step verification system to prevent such incidents, which involves an extra step after typing the username and password, followed by a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. This system was not previously in place, making it vulnerable to attacks using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple has since made this system the default option and introduced an email notification for backup downloads. However, there are concerns about the recovery key being hard to remember and the risk of it being stolen. Experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default for all companies, not just Apple. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP won the May election with a campaign expenditure of £2,956,737, while the Tories spent £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, losing all but one of their MEPs, and Labour spent £1,027,339, coming second. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p, the Conservatives' was 79p, and the Lib Dems' was £1.45 per vote. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249 on its campaign, with a spending of 43p per vote. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning, all spending more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign, except for Labour.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow and joined their rivals in the National League. He has experience playing in Italy and England. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams. He has played for several Irish clubs and his move to Gulls is subject to international clearance. Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage and had no significant underlying health issues. This incident is rare in horses and all sports, and the racing industry aims to understand its cause and prevent it. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. He had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past but had never collapsed before.

The passage discusses the farewell addresses of three Scottish politicians - Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil - who are stepping down as MSPs ahead of the Scottish election on May 5. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional as Salmond and McNeil bid farewell. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for Holyrood to assume greater governance responsibility. He also joked about the Cheltenham racecourse and wished the election candidates good luck. McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, warned Holyrood about the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition, and expressed sadness that they had to learn from Westminster. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage announces the casting and production details for a live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson will play Belle, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, with filming starting at Shepperton Studios in May. Bill Condon, known for Dreamgirls and Twilight films, will direct.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects involved in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans lost their lives. The disaster occurred during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest. New inquests last year concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS is considering evidence files related to 15 suspects connected to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and eight related to an IPCC probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police.
