Relatives of the victims will be informed of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington. The families are hopeful for accountability but anticipate a long road ahead.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with one former inmate claiming the prison is flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice stated that staff work hard to prevent contraband, and the Justice Secretary has asked for suggestions to improve this. A nearby resident has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. The prison has invited residents to an evening discussion on what to do if contraband is thrown over. The former inmate also claimed drones are used to fly contraband goods to prison windows, but the Ministry of Justice denies this. Laws have been introduced to jail smugglers for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered severe head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, who was driving his VW Golf and failed to stop for a red light. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, has admitted to causing the accident but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is currently in residential care and Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating that he understands she was loved by the children and that he is "truly sorry" for what he has done to her and her family. The trial continues.

24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, Muir, will not be able to participate in the Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies that start in May. She finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir loves running for Scotland and is gutted about missing the Commonwealths but prioritizes completing her final year of studies. She believes she has at least two more Olympics in her and is considering the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir's 5,000m time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds was her new outdoor personal best.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, disappeared on his way home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search for him started in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations and expected to last several weeks. CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance shows him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. The man is believed to be the same one seen with him later on Haddington Road. The man has not yet been identified, and gardaí are appealing for his presence.

Juan Del Potro, ranked 165th, secured a victory over Stan Wawrinka in the second round of the Australian Open. Del Potro, who missed over two years due to injury, will now face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, struggled in the first set but fought back to win the match. Australia's Nick Kyrgios also advanced to the third round, defeating Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios, with the winner facing either Andy Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia was facing expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against CAF, but was allowed to participate after apologizing. Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears, but the ban was overturned after CAF reduced a fine from $1m to $50,000. Tunisia won a controversial penalty in the quarter-finals against Equatorial Guinea, which led to a row with CAF. The Tunisians were later allowed to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

McLaren, a long-term participant in F1 with a history of triumph and decline, is currently experiencing a slump. They started losing their way in 2013 with a chassis design issue, but have since regained their mojo with a new car. However, their Honda power-unit is causing problems. McLaren has a rich history, including two world championships and 182 race wins, but has also faced scandals like the 'lie-gate' in 2008. Despite their current struggles, McLaren's team principal, Ron Dennis, believes they are on the verge of a comeback and will soon break Mercedes' F1 dominance. Fernando Alonso returned to the team in 2015, hoping to win his third title with the renewed Honda partnership.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death. Despite police arriving to find people still inside, alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000, and Thomas £1,000. The judge expressed concern about the bar's poor management and O'Neill's "appalling record".

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry entered the game four shy of his mark of 272 three-pointers, which he set two years ago. He hit six before halftime and eight overall, teaming with Klay Thompson to bring the Warriors back from 13 points down. Curry added nine assists, and Thompson scored 26 to help Golden State avoid its first three-game losing streak this season. The Blazers were led by Lamarcus Aldridge with 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard with 20 points and eight assists. The Bulls easily wiped out a 19-point halftime deficit to deal a huge blow to Miami's playoff hopes, with Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scoring 14 points. Mike Dunleavy

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, a free-kick specialist, arrived at Melwood. They initially thought he was a competition winner. However, Van Velzen showcased his skills, impressing the players and even teaching them a dead-ball masterclass. Balotelli and Lambert watched as Van Velzen scored a goal, and later, Balotelli scored a perfect free-kick. Van Velzen, who has gained fame by uploading free-kick videos, was amazed by the experience and enjoyed pretending to be a poor free-kick shooter. He also revealed Balotelli's famous T-shirt with the slogan "I am what I am" during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

The passage discusses the benefits of having oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) for women with breast cancer caused by the BRC1 gene, as demonstrated by Hollywood star Angelina Jolie. Women with this gene variant have a 50-80% risk of developing breast cancer. Jolie had a double mastectomy and oophorectomy, reducing her risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%. A study of 676 breast cancer patients with the BRC1 or BRC2 gene showed that having an oophorectomy reduced the 20-year survival rate by 23.4% without the procedure. However, for BRC2 carriers, there was no significant drop in breast cancer death. Oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes. For BRC1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years, there was a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never underwent the procedure. The protective effect of o

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, aged 38 and 33 respectively, were fatally struck by an Amtrak train (train no. 80, the Carolinian) on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was heading north from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. Neither of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, but a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The Lowes were both pronounced dead at the scene. The train continued on its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. A man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal mentioned that they may have lived in a homeless camp. The accident caused a delay of almost three hours for the train. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh. The trip from Charlotte to New York City usually takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss and sought asylum in the US. He worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years, providing information on his former bosses and associates, and helped carry out undercover stings around the world. Despite his valuable contributions, Toro was not paid for his work and was only promised US citizenship, which was never delivered. Toro's final temporary visa expired in January 2023, and he is now facing deportation to Colombia, where he fears for his life due to his past work. He has been declining health and has been living in the US illegally. The DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship and Toro has been sentenced to death by the US government. He has been working with DEA agent Mike McManus to gain a green card or passport and social security benefits, but is now preparing to go into hiding if necessary

The US body responsible for internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for allegedly using the new '.sucks' domain name to extort money from celebrities and companies. The company, which was initially approved by ICANN, has been criticized by an advisory panel for its practices. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for '.sucks' domains from trademark holders and celebrities in March, with names being sold for around $2,000 by resellers. ICANN has received a letter from the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs regarding the company's actions. If found illegal, ICANN could declare Vox Populi in breach of its contract and seek to change the registry's behavior. The advisory body has called the '.sucks' domains a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory."

A mother of a baby boy, whose body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond in 1988, was arrested 27 years later. The baby was identified through DNA samples, which led police to the mother who admitted to being the boy's mother. The baby was stillborn, and there was no foul play involved. The mother was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church, Norfolk.

Michael Young, a former soldier, unlawfully imprisoned passenger Kristopher Hicks by driving him back to the rank in Bath after Hicks objected to going home. Hicks jumped from the moving car, sustaining severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and requiring round-the-clock care. The high court ruled in favor of Hicks, and Young is now ordered to pay compensation, with the exact amount yet to be decided. The family had requested hundreds of thousands of pounds, and the judge agreed that Hicks is entitled to a settlement for specialist rehabilitation and care. Hicks was 23 at the time of the incident.

Multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night, with one potentially touching down near Potosi, Missouri. The storms caused damage, flooding, and hail in various areas. More storms are expected in the following days.

Luke Rockhold, a California-based fighter, is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago and is targeting a title shot. He believes Machida's style, which involves dancing and running around, can be exploited by cutting him off and slowly progressing, making him fight Rockhold's way. Rockhold respects Machida's skills but is confident in his ability to dominate the fight, citing his speed and hip movement as advantages. Machida, who also has a victory in Brazil, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. He believes he can apply his strategy and technique to stop Rockhold and deserves a title shot if he wins. Both fighters are well-prepared for the bout, with Rockhold having eight weeks of camp and Machida having trained with Glover Teixeira.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale after the incident, landing safely. The most common causes of a gear-up landing are human error, where the pilot forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown, or mechanical fault, when an electric motor or a hydraulic actuator fails. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted to being disappointed with midfielder Yaya Tourié's performance this season. Despite criticism, Pellegrini vowed to support Tourié until the end of the season. City is looking to overhaul their aging squad at the end of a faltering campaign and is open to offers for Tourié. Tourié, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week deal, has been criticized for his performances amid City's Premier League defense collapse. Pellegrini also faced questions over his own future. City is currently in 5th place but defeat against West Ham could allow Liverpool to close the gap. City will also be without captain Vincent Kompany due to a muscle injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart insisted players should take responsibility for their poor performances, while City boss Pellegrini retained the backing of the dressing room. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cress

The article is about a Sicilian mafia fugitive named Domenico Rancadore, who was convicted in Italy for his role in the Cosa Nostra mafia and sentenced to seven years in prison in 1999. He was later extradited to Italy in 2013 after spending more than 20 years in the UK. However, his extradition was later dropped due to the expiration of his European Arrest Warrant, which had been issued in 2013. The warrant had been issued in error, as Rancadore's sentence had already expired in October 2014. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) failed to appeal against the district judge's decision to deny extradition in March 2014, which resulted in a loss of time and allowed Rancadore's lawyers to file an application for the sentence to be declared expired. The CPS has admitted to making a mistake by failing to serve appeal papers to Rancadore's lawyers on time in March last year, which could have resulted in R

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He will be ridden by AP McCoy, who will have six rivals, including Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, as his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalized until Friday morning. Ironically, it was after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February that AP McCoy shocked the racing world by announcing his intention to quit riding. Other runners in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The mother of a girl who was murdered 40 years ago, Virginia Trimble Ritter, has recently expressed her desire to see the crime scene photos of her daughter's body. Marcia, Virginia's daughter, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. However, last year, she asked the lead investigator, Mickey Miller, to show her the photos, which he did on his laptop. The photos revealed Marcia's body to be swollen, with blackened mouth and face, and signs of strangulation and sexual assault. Ritter expressed her desire for revenge after viewing the photos. Barrett was arrested in 2006 and found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009, receiving a 44-year sentence. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved mur

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, believes it's unthinkable that he won't win the Masters to complete his career Grand Slam. He had a final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011, which he considers the most important day of his career. McIlroy aims to claim his first Green Jacket and become one of the six players to win all four major titles, following Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, McIlroy is determined to complete his Grand Slam with a victory at Augusta later this month. He feels that winning the Masters would be a significant achievement and a testament to his complete player status. McIlroy has been looking forward to the Masters, as it brings so much hype and build-up, and he knows he won't be able to wait to get on the golf course and play.

The passage discusses various trending stories from the week, including natural phenomena like rainbows appearing in the New York area, a fashion company CEO capturing the image, and exotic dancers becoming a common practice in rural China. It also mentions celebrity news, such as RDJ's agitation during an interview, the lip plumping trend using a jar, and a 102-year-old woman going back in time with help from filmmakers. Additionally, there are stories about a school's prom-posal controversy, Ewan McGregor playing Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's transformation in the 'Black Mass' trailer, and a creative way to announce pregnancy by referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. Lastly, it mentions a military dad photobombing his son.

272 children in England were hospitalized due to Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) last year. The actual number of affected children could be much higher. According to the World Health Organization, at least one in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer learning, behavioral, or physical problems due to alcohol exposure. This equates to about 7,500 children every year. FAS can lead to lifelong issues, and there is no cure. A teenager named Niamh Brown, who was born with FAS, struggles with daily tasks and has cognitive delays. The Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust was set up to help others affected by alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Pregnant women are advised not to drink alcohol, with a maximum consumption of two units no more than twice a week if they do. However, some experts believe the guidance should be changed to a complete ban on alcohol during pregnancy.

A 31-year-old man, Shaun Andrew McKerry, also known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," attempted to rob a post office and store in Shildon, County Durham, on March 15 at 8 PM. He waved an axe and demanded cash from the terrified assistant, Andrea Brighty. However, he was tackled by the owner, Sab Dhillon, who was unaware of the robbery. While they wrestled, Dhillon's wife, Sam, helped by hitting McKerry with a baseball bat twice, disarming him and revealing his face to the cameras. McKerry was arrested by the police minutes later and sentenced to six years in prison. He had a history of crimes, including shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary, and was known for always returning home after committing a crime.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fuelled party at a Canadian barracks. They were ordered to surrender their passports and live at the nearby Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The accused, who are currently employed by the Navy, will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay. The victim, a woman in her early 20s living in Halifax, had accompanied a friend who had been invited to attend the party by local Canadian servicemen. The alleged sexual assault took place on April 10 after the sailors had returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The accused appeared in court and were ordered to return to court on May 27, with bail conditions including not leaving the province of Nova Scotia, not contacting the victim or six witnesses, not applying

The passage is about a mother, Valerie Jackson, whose four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red and scaly. Despite being shocked when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse due to the severity of RJ's skin condition, Valerie has been subjected to ignorance and taunts from the public. She has had to deal with people mistaking RJ's condition for abuse, being denied entry to play centers, and facing cruel comments from strangers. Despite the challenges, Valerie is determined to raise awareness about Netherton's Syndrome and hopes that as RJ grows older, people will become more knowledgeable about the condition.

The campaign against the "Are You Beach Body Ready?" adverts by protein world has gained significant traction, with over 50,000 signatures on a change.org petition. The adverts, featuring a toned model named Renee Somerfield, have been criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image and objectifying women. The advertising standards authority has received over 200 complaints, and Transport for London has removed the posters due to their three-week advertising period ending. The removal of the posters comes as a protest against protein world in Hyde Park is organized, with hundreds of people expected to attend. The campaign has sparked a debate on social media, with users criticizing the adverts for their sexist and unrealistic portrayal of women. Protein world has defended their campaign, stating that it is targeted at health-conscious individuals looking to get fit in time for summer. However, the company has also faced threats and a bomb threat, and the advertising standards authority is investigating the complaints. Despite the controversy, sales of protein powder have

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite main party leaders pledging to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has intervened after receiving a letter from First Great Western (FGW) regarding their decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds. FGW has urged Cameron to "urgently review" their decision, which will force customers to pay £62.40 for an off-peak return from May 17, a 87% increase from the current £33.30. The planned changes have angered Cameron's constituents, and other sharp price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands, a anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin, and an anytime first-class day return on Virgin from Manchester to Stoke. Virgin has stated that the majority of their price hikes affected "virgin trains-only

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blind in one eye after thugs threw a brick at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. He was confronting them about throwing stones at his property when the brick struck him in the left eye. Despite undergoing emergency surgery, he lost his eyesight in that eye. The attack occurred just three weeks after the couple got married. Police are investigating the incident with no known motive, suspecting it might be a case of yobs "messing around". The couple, who have no children, are moving out of their home due to fear of further violence.

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire's 25-year-old wicketkeeper, has signed a new one-year contract extension. He missed the 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that claimed his father's life. Poynton underwent an ankle operation and made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and will commit to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, hoping the new contract will give him confidence to perform well this summer. Poynton has shown good form since returning to training and in Abu Dhabi.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, who battled cancer, has been given the all-clear by doctors. He was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Despite his diagnosis, Harley felt stronger while undergoing radiotherapy, thanks to his ninja turtle mask. After his story gained media attention, Nickelodeon sent him Ninja Turtle presents. Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, an operation, and a stem cell transplant. He also had weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. Doctors confirmed him cancer-free, and his family is overjoyed. Harley's bravery and positive attitude during treatment have inspired him to become a face of Cancer Research UK's kids and teens campaign.

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, advises Jack Grealish to focus on his club career and force his way into the Villa first team. Grealish, 19, impressed against Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final and is wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood had a similar situation with Nabil Bentaleb, who chose Algeria over France. Grealish is expected to make a decision at the end of the season, and his dad, Kevin, agrees that he should concentrate on his club football first. Sherwood wants Grealish to play more games for Villa to improve his decision-making process.

The passage discusses the high costs of private jet landings, particularly at popular transport hubs for the wealthy and famous. Some of the most expensive airports for landing fees include Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Japan, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan, Dublin Airport in Dublin, Ireland, Bristol Airport in Bristol, England, and La Guardia Airport in New York, United States. These airports charge thousands of dollars for private jet landings. The most expensive airport is Haneda Airport, where planes are charged £4,559 (approximately $6,850) for landing. Other expensive airports include Tokyo's Narita International Airport (£3,728 or $5,600), Kansai International Airport in Osaka (£3,594 or $5,400), Dublin Airport (£2,729 or $4,100), Bristol Airport (£2

Cooper, a Labrador, and his friend Daisy, a small female pup, were taken by their owner Katie Gallegos to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. Cooper, who eats very quickly, gobbles down the ice cream cone in one bite, while Daisy takes a few ladylike licks. The video of this incident has been watched over seven million times, with some viewers finding it cute and hilarious, while others criticize Gallegos for feeding her dogs the treat. Gallegos defends her actions, stating that Cooper is in amazing health and that she lost her previous dog, a large breed mutt, at 19 years old who also enjoyed ice cream once a week. The dogs have also been seen visiting a Starbucks for a 'pup-uccino', with Cooper consuming the entire cup.

Gary Locke, previously Kilmarnock's interim manager, has been appointed permanently after signing a three-year deal. He joined the club as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer and took over as manager when Johnston left at the start of February. Since then, Locke has lost only once in seven games. He will hold a press conference on Friday morning to discuss his new role.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the smell of essential oils he wears. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are used by Kemp to help combat Logan's autism. Despite the oils having a positive impact on Logan's calmness and focus, teachers complained about the smell, leading to a threat of removal from class. Kemp received a letter from the local school board stating that the oils had created a problem for staff and students. However, on Thursday, Lake County School District stated it was a health issue and would not suspend Logan. The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which are described by Doterra as beautifully and powerfully fragrant.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, open from May to November, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread rapidly, melting paint off nearby buildings and causing 90 condos to be obliterated. Firefighters used cranes to approach the fire, but could not enter the building. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with claims it started near a parked car. The building manager lost everything and was distraught during the incident.

The Queen, aged 88, enjoyed a ride in Windsor Great Park on a sunny morning, accompanied by her faithful black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. She has never worn riding helmets, preferring a silk scarf instead, due to her hair. The Queen has a long-standing love for horses, having been presented with a Shetland pony at four and riding with her first pony, Peggy, since then. She has bred several breeds of horses and ponies, including Fell ponies, which have roamed the moors of Cumbria since the Neolithic period. The Queen continues to ride and breed Fell ponies, despite cutting back due to a knee injury.

55-year-old Leon Yeaman was fatally punched by 28-year-old Phillip Pama, a married father of three, during a noise dispute in North Brisbane. Pama, who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse, was granted conditional bail after being charged with manslaughter. Neighbours described Yeaman as generous but some also mentioned he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed loud music. Pama, who has no history of violence, was reportedly distressed over the incident. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-pupil, Damian Vanya, after their relationship ended. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the deed. The police set up a sting operation, and Simonova was arrested after handing over expenses money to an undercover officer posing as a hitman. She was charged with attempted murder and remanded in custody. Damian had been showered with gifts and money by Simonova before ending the relationship with his classmate.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's manager, has a strong faith in God and prays daily, but only discusses football with his wife occasionally. He believes in separating his professional and personal life, and never prays about football. Mourinho is known for his arrogant on-field persona but considers himself a good person off-field, supporting people he doesn't know and acknowledging mistakes in his professional life. Chelsea are currently top of the league, and Mourinho was fined for claiming a 'campaign' against them. He attended the Hunger Games premiere with his family and celebrated Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory with players.

Bob Barker, who hosted The Price is Right for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years. He handled the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over to the current host, Drew Carey. Despite the long break, Barker seemed to adapt well to the role.

Off-duty secret service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was hit with felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin was arrested on the 3200 block of D Street SE by the Metropolitan Police. The agency revoked his security clearance and put him on leave. The Foreign Missions Branch, which Baldwin is posted to, deals with the U.S.'s diplomatic activities. Baldwin was to be arraigned on Friday afternoon, but there is no information on an attorney or contact number. His arrest comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave for misconduct, which is being investigated by police. The Homeland Security Department's Inspector General is also investigating the allegations of misconduct by the supervisor. This is the latest in a series of incidents involving the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion at a safari park. He got out of his car and crept up to the lion, armed only with a camera, managing to capture a few frames before the lion was alerted by the camera's shutter sound and retreated rapidly. Saeed described the encounter as a close one, where he was treated like prey by the lion and had to quickly scramble into his car. He admitted that he might not attempt such a stunt again.

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found dead in Brooklyn on March 22. She had a distinctive heart tattoo with the name 'Monique' on her right leg, but had no other identification. The police are seeking information to identify her and determine the cause of her death. The tattoo was found by NYPD and released to the public in hopes of identifying the woman.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from living in the UK. They wanted a cozy and affordable home but couldn't afford a full-sized lot. After a year and a half of construction, they completed the project, which included a wood-lined interior, stained glass windows, and a wood-fired stove for heat. The home is powered mostly by solar panels, and they aim to build another one like this in the future. The project cost them around $25,000.

The passage discusses a study by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University in the US, which found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes over an academic year significantly outscored their peers who were in classes that had no iPads or in which each student had their own device. The shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device on their own and non-ipad users. The study suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just the collaboration, made the difference. The researcher recommends that schools reconsider how the tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage tells the story of a piglet named "super pig" from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China, who was born with missing hind legs. Despite this, the piglet has learned to walk on its front trotters and has become an internet sensation. The video shows the piglet taking unsteady steps and wobbling while foraging for food. The piglet's ability to balance on its two front trotters is remarkable, as it often looks close to tipping over but always manages to regain its balance. The piglet lives with other piglets who have all four legs, and one of them has been observed trying to copy the two-legged creature. The piglet's story is not unique, as another rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also gained fame for walking on its front paws. The piglet's heartwarming video has attracted thousands of viewers and has captured the hearts of many.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured on Sunday during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. He was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment, receiving stitches for a cut on his leg and was later released. Many cars struggled with traction due to hours of rain before the race started. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, due to jealousy over men looking at her. The crime was captured on CCTV, showing Severiano attacking her with a concrete paving 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. The couple had only been married for four days when the incident occurred. Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was later apprehended after crashing it during his escape. He confessed to the murder and faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, including anxiety, in a candid interview. She revealed that her anxiety drove her to believe her life was not worth living, and she came close to taking her own life. Wilson explained that it was a combination of factors, including mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and distant family, that led her to feel this way. She felt increasingly isolated and alone, with no husband or children, and struggled to see a way out of her situation. Wilson has recently found some peace with her past and acknowledges the link between depression and anxiety. She believes that Australian women are being negatively affected by stress and anxiety, and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and depression and anxiety are often interconnected. If you or someone you know needs help, contact B

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant at the time, found the ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave. When the ex-girlfriend refused, Curtin beat her with the crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin was seven-months pregnant when she was charged and gave birth in January. The ex-girlfriend had a history of drug use and had previously gotten high at the apartment with the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child. The ex-girlfriend and the boyfriend had struggled with heroin addiction in the past. Curtin is now living with her parents and has not been a part of her new child's life. If she had gone to trial and been convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory pr

Gemma, a Pit Bull, was filmed being fed treats at home in California. Her owner tried to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to the mix, but Gemma immediately showed disgust, chomped on it, and spit it out. The owner hopes the two children Gemma lives with don't follow her lead and learn to enjoy vegetables. Other videos show Gemma enjoying sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC, a banking giant, apologized after a link on its official website directed users to a pornographic site. The link, which was active from 2011 to 2021, was part of the bank's now-defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page. The bank removed the hyperlink after realizing the mistake and denied any association with the external site. HSBC's internet banking service, which includes features like account balance checks, fund transfers, and loan/insurance applications, remains secure.

A 13-year-old boy from Maryland, Marcus, called 911 after smelling smoke and discovering his family trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to a fire on the first floor of their home in Clinton. He remained calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing instructions to firefighters and reassuring his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah. Marcus guided them to the back hallway and a black door to the right, which led to the exit. Firefighters rescued Marcus and Aaliyah, along with their other family members, who escaped on their own, and took them to the hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.

Blue fluorescent algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, have caused a beautiful supernatural glow on Australia's East Coast, including Jervis Bay and Manly Beach. This phenomenon occurs naturally in spring and autumn and is caused by the algae's defense mechanism. The algae preys on diatoms and emits light to deter predators. An oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales confirmed that the glow is due to natural causes and occurs in 90% of cases.

Breast cancer patients may avoid chemotherapy through new genetic tests that identify tumor markers and determine aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, providing results within days. Some tests, like Endopredict, can accurately predict a low risk of recurrence (as low as 5%), which is comparable to or better than chemotherapy odds. Experts believe that for certain women, chemotherapy is not necessary due to lower recurrence risks. These tests are currently available privately for around £2,500, and there's a case for NHS adoption based on potential savings from not providing chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer survivor, avoided chemotherapy after receiving a low score on the Endopredict test, which indicated a 5% chance of recurrence within ten years. Regular monitoring is recommended to catch any potential cancer recurrence early.

25+ women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. HMS Ocean had 5 emergency evacuations, and at least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious (formerly HMS Lusty). Eighteen other ships had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting conception before boarding or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first female warship captain, was flown back to the UK after claims of a sexual relationship. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant, and 99 servicewomen on operations were flown back to the UK between 2006 and 2013. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and women are reminded to check they

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence, on Wednesday. The drone, 50 centimeters wide with four propellers, was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount inside is not immediately harmful to humans. The discovery has raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, with Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stating that there might be terrorism attempts in the future at the Olympics and G7 summit using drones. The government will review and examine ways to prevent such threats. Japan law restricts drone flights around airports, but there are no restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence and local and federal government buildings. Prime Minister Abe was not in his office at the time and was in Indonesia attending the Asian-African conference.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother with him to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He does this because he is scared she will get lost if left alone at home. His mother used to get lost when she was left alone, as she suffered from the degenerative disease. Lu's wife works in a different city and his son is still in school, so there is no one else to look after his mother. Lu rides slowly to work to ensure his mother's safety and checks up on her at work. He feels a duty to care for his mother in return, as she devoted her life to caring for her children.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with a significant increase in women's drinking habits. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month, also saw a rise of nearly 36% in Santa Clara County, California, and more than seven times the rate among men nationwide. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, with the percentage of people who drink any alcohol remaining relatively unchanged over time. The increase in binge drinking has been linked to changed social norms, affluent people's ability to drink more, and wealthy professionals moving to cities like San Francisco, San Jose, and Oakland. Public health experts also attribute the increase to taxes on al

The passage discusses the increasing rate of caesarean sections in England, which has more than doubled since the early 1990s, now accounting for over a quarter of all births. The World Health Organisation (WHO) and the UN's public health agency warn that the ideal rate should be between 10-15%, due to the dangers and costs involved. They state that caesarean sections are often performed without medical need, putting women and babies at risk of short- and long-term health problems, significant complications, disability, or death. The WHO also mentions that planned caesareans cost the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth at £1,665. The NHS guidelines currently allow caesarean sections to be offered even without medical justification, but the WHO contradicts this, stating that doctors are carrying them out too often and underestimating the risks. Previous research has found that up to one in ten caesareans can cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, a 44-year-old woman from West Wareham, has been arrested and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She allegedly broke into a $800,000 summer home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins on April 17 and confronted her, but she claimed ownership of the house. Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck and was later arrested when she attempted to re-enter the home. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone was reunited with its owner, Bella Crooke from Melbourne, after Albury Police posted bizarre photos on her Facebook page. The phone was handed in at the police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police officers used the phone to post selfies and messages on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a "holding cell." Bella realized her phone was missing at a friend's birthday party the night before and dialed her number as soon as she realized. A security guard picked up the phone and left it at the police station. Bella arrived at the police station around 1 PM and found the original post had already garnered humorous responses from her friends and officers. The phone was still at the police station when Bella reclaimed it, and she didn't have to give her name as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police had been texting Bella's friends on her behalf with humorous messages. Bella has since put a password on her phone and thanked the police for returning it.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was mauled to death after getting caught up in a fight between two adult hippos in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as her baby was flung into the air and dragged along the water's surface. The two male hippos had been fighting for some time, and the mother likely believed it safer to stay out of harm's way. However, one of the sub-adult hippos grabbed the calf, and the mother tried to get it back but was unsuccessful. The calf died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom apartment in London's Knightsbridge, one of the most expensive areas to live in Britain, is being sold for £575,000 with a three-year lease remaining. The property, described as a "bright and well-proportioned" space with 1,990 sq/ft, has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. However, it needs modernization and has just three years left on the lease. If extended, the property could be worth up to £6 million. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease would cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease. The properties in Egerton Place, built in 1893, introduced a higher quality of architecture to the area. Potential buyers should be aware of the need for modernization and the high cost of extending the lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to stop functioning and leading to free drinks being given away. The outage began in the early evening on the east coast and in the late afternoon on the west coast. The cause of the outage was not disclosed. The company assured customers that stores would remain open and continue serving customers, and that the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. Despite the outage, many customers took advantage of the free drinks on social media, sharing photos of their free-of-charge drinks. However, some locations closed early to avoid giving away free products during the shutdown. The outage also affected Starbucks' Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. The tech snafu came just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. This radicalization process involves seemingly ordinary activities but has an ulterior motive. The British military uses these areas for training, preparing soldiers physically and mentally for warfare. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, with Hate preacher Abu Hamza sending a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, Powys. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting at the National Whitewater Centre in Bala, North Wales. In 2017, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for plotting a 'Mumbai-style' series of terror attacks on Britain. DC Jones, an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, emphasized that issues surrounding terror

A species of whale, Omura's whale, was found washed up on a West Australian beach, giving scientists an opportunity to learn more about the mammal. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68 m juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling after initial struggles by department of parks and wildlife staff. The find is significant for whale scientists as little is known about the species, which is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried and will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possibly public display in museums.

The passage discusses the issue of women in leadership, particularly in the context of presidential candidates. It highlights the concern that a woman's hormones might impact their decision-making, with some arguing that this could lead to unnecessary wars. The text also mentions that male hormones have impaired the decision-making of some male leaders in the past. However, it is noted that studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. The passage also mentions that women leaders face bias in the workplace, with some people believing that women have a "our place" and that place is not at the table. The text also mentions that Hillary Clinton, a female presidential candidate, would face additional challenges due to her gender. The passage concludes by emphasizing the importance of equality and the benefits it brings to individuals, families, and the economy.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small and as Winston Churchill, is selling his extensive antiques collection of over 200 items due to downsizing his home. The collection includes a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a hand-painted limewood diorama, a longbow made from yew, and various paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire. Hardy, who has built the collection through his interest in classic literature and military history, has published two books on the history of the longbow and was consulted as an expert during the raising of the Tudor shipwreck, the Mary Rose. He is sad to sell his collection but hopes that those who purchase his items will find joy and pleasure from them as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. The body was discovered after an out-of-state family member called for a well-being check. Authorities believe there was foul play involved. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His estranged wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors believe divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been selected to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the IAAF Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host in the USA. Eugene previously bid unsuccessfully for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The IAAF Council chose to grant the championships to Eugene, citing a unique opportunity to collaborate with public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. This decision aligns with the 2007 World Championships held in Osaka, Japan, which was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death by pretending to be a wealthy woman. She targeted him at a London casino and used her good looks to befriend him, showering him with gifts, cash, and trips. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in prison. Her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The trial heard that Granger had been in love with Jackson and fell in with his desires, leading her to become deceitful and lose her sense of compassion. The defendants were also convicted of robbing Hassan, conspiracy to falsely imprison him, and other related charges.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, particularly since his return to England. His form has significantly dipped from his promising start, leading to questions about his durability. He has been given poor ratings for his performances, including a 4/10 by a Spanish newspaper. Despite being a key player for Spain and Chelsea, his form has not been consistent, with a long, intense campaign taking its toll. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas' fatigue and his role as a key man in the team's title charge. Fabregas has struggled to make an impact in midfield, particularly in Chelsea's defeat by Holland. He has been brilliant for Chelsea in some games but has struggled since. His form has dropped off somewhat, and he has just one Premier League assist in five games since mid-January. Despite his unwanted reputation for a late-season slump, Fabregas has laid on goals for Chel

West Ham United are in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a trial period. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. In other news, West Ham has announced that season tickets for the 2016-17 Barclays Premier League season at the Olympic Stadium will be as low as £289, making them the cheapest in the league to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium.

The passage discusses a violent assault on Mike Lane, 40, a joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, by hunt saboteurs wearing balaclavas and armed with iron bars. The attack occurred on January 24 near Amesbury, where the hunt was chasing an artificial scent. Lane was severely injured, including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The face of the main suspect was captured on video, but the police have not identified, charged, or prosecuted anyone involved. The police stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, which has dismayed hunt supporters. The incident has also led to calls for better police action against saboteurs wearing face coverings.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who was born in 1978 and grew up on a farm in rural California, became a prominent member of Al Qaeda after converting to Islam in 1995. He was known as Azzam the American. Gadahn was tasked with greeting Al Qaeda operatives at Peshawar airport in 1998 and later rose through the ranks in the tribal areas of Pakistan, becoming the chief official English-language propagandist. He was known for his English-language propaganda videos, including ones threatening attacks on Los Angeles and Melbourne, Australia. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda and was among the FBI's "Most Wanted Terrorists." He was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January 2015, but neither he nor another U.S. citizen and Al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, were specifically targeted. Gadah

A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old, has gained significant attention in China for his exceptional skills. The viral video showcases his ability to score hoops and dribble multiple basketballs simultaneously with remarkable focus and rhythm. His talent has earned him a massive following across the country, with even China's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming, being compared to him. Netizens are stunned by his potential and have been leaving comments praising his skills, with some feeling ashamed of their own basketball abilities.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which advocated for legalizing child sex in the 70s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key PIE activist, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. This is an embarrassment for Hacked Off, as PIE was formed in 1974 to campaign for sex with children to be legalized and formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL). The NCCL lobbied parliament for the age of sexual consent to be cut to ten and wanted incest to be legalized. O'Carroll was on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals'. He wrote a blog after the February meeting, chaired by comedian John Cleese, confirm

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, serving as a unique catwalk setting for Ten Pieces' presentation. The event, headlined by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome collection of ten pieces designed for day-to-night wear. The show took place on a warm 28 degrees Celsius day, with beachgoers stopping to watch from the road above the pool. The collection, suitable for both sexes, featured androgynous wares and was served with minimalist, androgynous designs and nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his family, including his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. He interacted with a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Earlier, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent. He had been under pressure to fight British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June, but Khan stated he was already in negotiations for a different opponent, possibly Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His family objected to his inclusion on the Jerusalem's Mount Herzl memorial wall, which commemorates fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. The family and an organization called Almagor, which works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, argued that Abu Khdeir's death was not a terror attack and that he should not be listed among soldiers of the occupation. The national insurance institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his family's complaints.

The passage is about a young boy who wants to use his cat as a pillow to rest. He chases the cat around the garden, but the cat keeps moving away. The boy repeats this process multiple times, but the cat eventually gets tired and walks indoors. Later, the boy and the cat are seen playing together peacefully, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia has resulted in a losing verdict for witness Robert Kushner, who lost his varsity coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government against allegations of police wrongdoing. He claimed that undercover officers had stolen cash and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, but this history was unknown to his employers. Kushner had passed a background check when he was hired to coach basketball in 2010. He was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. The six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering have claimed the government's case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured by broken glass after an explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province that produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but there's no report of toxic chemical spill. More than 600 firefighters battled the blaze, which is now under control. The plant had a similar explosion in July 2013 with no casualties or toxic leaks reported. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in China, including in the city of Xiamen where the zhangzhou plant was slated for, but it was relocated due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and not using shinpads. He has a superstition about it and won't change. Despite some referees' attempts to tell him otherwise, he insists on his style. His first Premier League start came in a 3-3 draw against QPR, which he found tough due to the relegation scrap. He's pleased to have made his start but disappointed with the outcome. He's hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is in a global and irreversible brain damage state, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Despite being out of the medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Doctors have indicated that she will have a long life, but the quality of her life is uncertain. Bobby Brown, her father, had previously stated that she was awake and watching him, but an attorney for the family later clarified that she is undergoing rehabilitation and the quality of her life is not yet known. Alicia Etheredge-Brown, Bobby Brown's wife, described her condition as having made it out of the ICU, opened her eyes, and starting a long rehabilitation process.

Russia are on the verge of qualifying for the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova overcame a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved the match point in the second set before winning 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Meanwhile, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia George in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova admitted that Lisicki's power was challenging, but Lisicki also mentioned that she had a match point but Pavlyuchenkova played a good point to avoid it. The result leaves Russia needing one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are bracing for more floods and damage due to another storm predicted to hit later this week. The same weather system that hit the state's east coast last week, an east coast low, is expected to return, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) has over 4,000 jobs still to be completed from the previous storm and is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts. The Hunter region, which suffered through flooding and high winds in the last storm, is particularly worried about the effect more wild weather will have on it. The Bureau of Meteorology suggests that the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds will be on coastal areas in the state's north-east, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland. The Bureau of Meteorology said it was too early to tell how severe the weather system will be. The SES will spend the next few days trying to complete as many jobs as possible and warning people

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" video, was treated in the hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure. She posted photos of heavy bruising on her arms on her Instagram account. Italian media initially reported that she tried to take her own life, but she denied this and claimed she was a victim of people trying to do her harm. She explained that she fell and hurt herself due to low blood pressure, not suicide. She was found by her mother in her apartment and is now recovering at home. Moric was once married to famous paparazzi Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebs with compromising photographs.

The British public are hoping for a baby girl and favor the name Diana for the second child of Kate and William, in honor of William's mother, Princess Diana. If it's a boy, 13% of people would like him to be named James, with Alexander as the second favorite. The poll was conducted by YouGov for The Sunday Times, involving 2,200 people. Many people are hoping for a girl, with a quarter of those polled expressing this desire. The choices were echoed on social media, with many users expressing their delight at the prospect of a baby girl named after Princess Diana. The poll also revealed that the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring dozens more. The incident occurred in Khost province, where an Afghan lawmaker was among the wounded. The Taliban denied involvement, and no other group had claimed responsibility. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The attack happened around 10 a.m. local time. CNN's Masoud Popalzai reported from Kabul, Jethro Mullen from Hong Kong, and Elizabeth Joseph contributed to the report.

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back, has played for Barcelona for seven successful years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he has been unable to agree on a new contract with the club and is set to leave Barcelona this summer. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves rejected Barcelona's final contract offer, which was contingent on playing in 60% of matches. Santana stated that the negotiations are over and it's unclear why Barcelona didn't consider renewing Alves' contract earlier.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently playing for Argentine giants Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the club. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti, who have established themselves as one of the best midfielders in world football and a roma legend respectively, would be a good fit for Boca and would be well-received by the fans. He thinks that their south-american style would be perfect for the club and the bombonera would go "crazy" for players like them.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson suffered a fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton, which was watched by hundreds of thousands online. He was undeterred and back riding out the next day, with only a cut on his nose as an injury. Ferguson described the fall as "spectacular" and "impressive," and considered the possibility of a career in gymnastics after racing.

James Haskell, a London Wasps captain, dressed as Iron Man from the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie for his Instagram post. He joined Wasps in 2002 and has since played 100+ appearances, winning 57 England caps. After leaving Wasps in 2009, he played in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to England in 2012. The Avengers: Age of Ultron movie premiered at Westfield London shopping centre with the A-list cast, including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson.

The wide leg trouser is a trend that emerged in SS15, available in various styles like denim, cropped, printed, or striped. It offers an alternative to the long-standing skinny jean trend. The wide leg can be intimidating on shorter individuals, but it can be made flattering with the right shoe choice, preferably high heels and simple tops. Denim is the easiest way to incorporate this trend into your wardrobe. Popular brands like Gucci, Celine, and Topshop have showcased wide leg trousers on their runways. To update your wardrobe without needing nice weather, consider a wide billowing trouser silhouette.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. The movie, which depicts the Iraq War and won Bradley Cooper an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, was initially planned as part of the university's social events series, Umix. However, over 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie due to its alleged negative portrayal of the Middle East and people from that region. The university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, later stated that the initial decision to cancel the showing was a mistake and that the movie will proceed as planned. The university also announced that a family-friendly movie, "Paddington," will be offered as an alternative for those who do not wish to watch "American Sniper." The announcement was met with praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were arrested for attempting to set a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, alight on April 3. They allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with the quokka. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The men were questioned, and video evidence was seized. They have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas can be found on some small islands off the Western Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a renowned dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen herself dance before as she had no access to her photographs or memorabilia. With the help of filmmakers and Mark Cantor of Jazz-on-Film.com, she watched early music videos, or "soundies," for the first time at a nursing home, expressing delight at seeing herself dance.

The passage discusses the decline in the traditional British practice of washing one's own car, which was once a common Sunday routine. A study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that a third of men have never washed their own car, and only 12% do it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. However, there is an increase in car washing during holidays, with one in four people doing it as an excuse to get out of the house. The study also reveals that cars are most likely to be washed in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW are the most washed cars, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are the least washed. The OSV spokesman attributes this change to busy schedules, larger cars, and the availability of automated car w

Martin Skrtel, a Slovakia international, has praised Steven Gerrard's impact at Liverpool since 2008. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and could end his career with a FA Cup final victory over Arsenal on his birthday, May 30. Skrtel, who has been with Liverpool since 2008, believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and has helped settle him at the club. Skrtel also acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes they have potential replacements. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool line-up for the match against Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit an ace in the par-3 contest at Augusta National, his first on the hallowed turf. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus had mentioned earlier that he only needed to win the par-3 and make a hole-in-one. The ace was part of a record-breaking day with five hole-in-ones, including Camilo Villegas who also had an ace on the fourth and eighth. However, Villegas couldn't win the title, losing to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus, who became the youngest Green Jacket winner in 1963 and collected his sixth in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night, with one near Goddard, Kansas, and others in southwestern Kansas and Potosi, Missouri. The storms brought reports of twisters, wind damage, flooding, and hail. Kansas is not the only state affected, with more storms expected in the midwest, Mississippi river valley, Tennessee river valley, and near the southern great lakes. Nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous and deadly.

Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claimed he meant to use a taser but accidentally shot Harris with a gun. The shooting was initially considered accidental, but the Harris family disagrees, alleging that Bates was not qualified for the force and received preferential treatment. They also claim that some supervisors were told to forge Bates' records and were reassigned when they refused. Bates' lawyers have denied these allegations and released training documents that they say prove he had proper law enforcement training. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irishman, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has unveiled a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, accompanied by the caption "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor is challenging Aldo for his featherweight championship title in Las Vegas. Aldo is defending his eighth title defense against McGregor. McGregor claims Aldo lacks motivation and doesn't want to be near him. They have a history of a fractious relationship, and McGregor believes he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo to defend it. At the end of March, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was criticized for skolling a beer at an Australian Rules function, which was seen as glorifying binge drinking and associating manhood with alcohol consumption. Cultural Studies Professor Julie Robert from the University of Technology Sydney expressed concern that such behavior sets a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing. She warned that people can forget their limits when they are caught up in the act of demonstrating their drinking abilities. While drinking is part of Australian tradition, Robert believes it's problematic to glorify irresponsible drinking practices and perpetuate the stereotype that heavy drinking makes one a true blue Australian. Critics argue that Abbott should set an example of not having to drink heavily to be an Australian. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that his early morning fitness routine is a positive example for the country. Abbott, who has been a rugby man all his life, was seen skolling a beer with the University of Technology

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, which is about 30 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky. This is a rise from the 106 cases reported last week. The outbreak is among intravenous drug users and primarily involves the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana. The state has seen about five HIV cases each year typically. Since Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary needle exchange program on March 26, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. The program has gained momentum with the mobile unit traveling around neighborhoods to reach more IV drug users. However, the future of the program and legislation for other counties is uncertain as Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. The Senate President Pro Tempore, David Long, is unsure if the emergency exchange for Scott County was the right reaction and if

Saskia, an Arsenal fan, took a test from her boyfriend to prove her knowledge about the club. She scored 87% and received praise from football fans for her answers. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and 'in your own words' sections. Saskia struggled with some questions, particularly naming the starting 11 players of the season.
