The United Nations (UN) held a conference in Geneva to improve global flight tracking systems. The current system, which relies on ground-based radars, was found to have weaknesses after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in 2014. The conference resulted in a decision to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a satellite tracking system, known as Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B), which will enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. This decision was made following the urging of Malaysia's communication minister and the recognition of the need for improved global flight tracking guidelines, with a deadline of November 2016 set by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) for adoption.

Julian Hernandez, a 18-year-old boy, disappeared at the age of five and was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby, 53, was arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI received a tip in October 2021 that Julian might be the missing child due to his college application issues. The agency worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. Julian's mother was notified of his recovery. Bobby is being held in the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected Bobby around the time of Julian's disappearance and believed he might have been involved.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street following a blaze on 2 March, which caused train service reductions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, but the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit after considering all facts. The company is required to remove all waste and will no longer operate from the site after 7 August, if not appealed. The cause of the fire is still unknown. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills linked to the situation in Ukraine. The first bill allows for a territory to become a part of the Russian Federation if a majority of its population expresses a desire to join, without the need for a treaty with a neighboring state. This is in response to the disintegration of Georgia's breakaway regions Abkhazia and South Ossetia, which were controlled by Russia after the 2008 war. The second bill speeds up the procedures for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly those who are Russian-speaking and defenseless against the "brown threat" (a reference to World War Two fascists). This bill would allow Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1 and become citizens after two months instead of a year. Several Russian MPs, including celebrities, have visited Crimea to support the proposed bills.

McLaren, a long-term participant in F1 with a history of triumph and decline, is currently experiencing a slump. They started losing their way in 2013 due to issues with their chassis design, but have since regained their mojo with the car. However, problems persist with the Honda power-unit. McLaren has a rich history of success, including winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and dominating the next four years. They also had a scandal in 2007 where they were found guilty of benefiting from Ferrari's technical information and were fined $100m. In recent years, they have had issues with misleading the stewards and a lack of titles. McLaren is currently in a period of slow decline, but team principal Ron Dennis insists that success will return soon, with the renewed Honda partnership being their best chance to win another title. Dennis believes that the car is among the very best this

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was found fatally injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. He was shot in the head and chest and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody for questioning. Baker left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before the shooting and detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. A silver VW Polo, which left the scene at speed, is being searched for. Several people captured on CCTV near the meat market have not come forward and their footage could be crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online, including Everyday Church Online, a virtual church service that has attracted 61 countries. It also mentions Guardians of Ancora, a fantasy game aimed at children that uses Bible stories to light up the world. The passage also highlights the use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities during the holiday season. Additionally, it mentions the Manga Messiah, a book in Manga form that contains the story of the nativity and has been distributed in 33 different languages. The passage also mentions the challenges of sharing the Gospel in 140 characters and the idea that Jesus would be on Twitter due to his communication skills.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing the proposal to utilize 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for a motorsport circuit. The proponents, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed around 320 hectares (800 acres) of alternative land. The inquiry has received conflicting expert opinions on the potential harm to habitats and plant life from building on the common land. Natural Resources Wales expressed uncertainty about the equal value of the replacement land but did not oppose the development. The developers' ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity due to additional habitat enhancement projects nearby, which the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees with. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation, and Welsh government ministers will ultimately decide on the project's approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a Novaya Gazeta report revealing over 100 detentions of homosexual individuals in Chechnya, with at least three reported killed. The report was denied by Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman, while the Chechens' spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, called for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network accused the Russian authorities of ignoring abuses and threatened to file a case at the International Criminal Court if no action is taken.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency, receives benefit payments for housing single homeless men in London. The charity, Fresh Start Housing, finds clients from homeless charities and refers them to Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions makes money by putting several unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, leading to higher benefit payouts than the rent fee passed on to the property's landlord. Both organizations are based in the same building and operate across seven London boroughs. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making the venture profitable. The company focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35, but housing benefit legislation allows people aged 35 and over to be housed in private accommodation, which can be charged at higher rates. Nigel McCann, a tenant, described the properties as unsuitable and said the company was more interested in profit than helping people. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1m in the past two years. Matt Downie, of homeless char

In the passage, the British men's basketball team, led by Coach Joe Prunty, played against the Netherlands. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13. The game was close throughout, with GB leading for most of the first three quarters. However, the Netherlands overtook them in the last 10 minutes. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's performance, who joined the team despite not making the London 2012 Olympics. GB will start their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary midweek, focusing on playing hard on both ends of the floor.

The passage discusses a boxing match between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather, which is set to be the richest fight in history. McGregor, a former UFC five-weight champion, will make his boxing debut in this bout. The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) has sanctioned the fight, and McGregor has submitted a necessary waiver to use 8oz gloves at 154lbs, which is the weight class for the fight. The NAC rules state that 10oz gloves are used from 135lbs upwards, but bouts between 135lbs and 147lbs can use 8oz gloves if waivers are signed and the NAC feels the move is justified. The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision. McGregor has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, and he welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post last week, stating that he would come at him with bricks. The fight has prompted criticism from major

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, has seen its share of history and change. It was the birthplace of the nation's biggest newspapers, with the first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, published there in 1702. For decades, it was the pinnacle of a journalist's career, with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices within a half-mile radius. However, the death of journalism has been announced too soon by some of London's tour guides, as Fleet Street is still home to journalists and freelancers. The street was famous for its many bars and pubs, where journalists would socialize and seek stories. The atmosphere was lively and fast-paced, with typewriters bashed about and phones not working properly. However, the advent of computerized printing technology and the move of national newspapers to other parts of London led to the decline of Fleet Street. Now, the buildings have morphed into other uses, and the last two journalists to leave have marked the end of an era

The Harry Potter author, J.K. Rowling, expressed her frustration with abusive comments she received on Twitter, stating that her personal line had been crossed. She had previously donated Â£1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum, which led to criticism. She also revealed that she had been called a traitor for her political views and had blocked some abusive users, including some who were believed to be SNP supporters. Despite this, she stated that she felt no responsibility to hush up such behavior. The SNP, which took 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland's election, is now the third largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study by the University of Edinburgh that found children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Living in poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The study, funded by various organizations, has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998. It found that poverty increases the risks of violence and that contact with the juvenile justice system can inadvertently reproduce conditions that foster violence. A separate report by the same organization showed that recent falls in crime rates in Scotland have not benefited areas with the most chronic rates of crime, which are still concentrated among poor people and within poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government spokesman responded that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live with recorded crime at a 41-year low, homicide figures at their lowest level in 39 years, and 1,000 extra officers on the streets. The

25-year-old Mr Haugh was stabbed in the early hours of Sunday in the Marian estate, Kilkee. Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody. Two other men arrested were released without charge. The incident involved a fight with weapons, including knives and golf clubs. Mr Haugh died from his injuries and Walsh's knife handle and blade were recovered at the scene with blood on it. Walsh will appear in court again next week.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about former UDR member Tom Elliott appearing on BBC radio, questioning if he would reveal the number of people he harassed and shot. Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. He has a clear MoD record. The tweet was deleted an hour later after being alerted to it by victims campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. Flanagan must apologize for the tweet, which was found to be untrue and without foundation. The insurance firm covering MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Flanagan for compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging in a separate court action. Elliott welcomed the vindication and expressed disappointment that it took so long to reach this stage.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, has seen increased production of sweaters to meet demand, boosted by better-than-expected sales of its branded range launched in January. The company, bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, has also seen growth in its private label supply business. Hawick Knitwear sells in Europe to countries like Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, and in markets outside Europe such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The company has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters per week, up from about 7,500 last year. Mr. Hartop expressed optimism about the company's future, attributing it to the dedicated staff and increased orders from both home and abroad for both private label clients and the company's own brand.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered severe head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, who was driving his VW Golf. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, admitted to hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The incident occurred outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, when Blackburn was on duty. Wright is a married father of three and has been driving for 30 years. The trial continues.

The passage discusses a NATO exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose" aimed at conducting anti-submarine warfare, primarily in response to growing threats from Russian submarines. The exercise involves various assets, including warships, helicopters, underwater unmanned vehicles, and maritime patrol aircraft. The Russian submarine U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, is acting as the unseen enemy, trying to avoid detection while attempting to take out the command ship USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the need for NATO members to be prepared for Russian submarine activity, as Russia has been increasing its military strength, particularly in submarine development. The lack of a UK maritime patrol aircraft is identified as a significant vulnerability, as it would make it difficult to track Russian submarines near British waters. The exercise aims to ensure NATO's readiness for anti-submarine warfare and to address the need for improved defenses against Russian submarine activity.

South Sudan, the world's youngest country, is currently experiencing a crisis with violence spreading from the capital Juba to the Equatoria states. Since July, 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda, with an average of 2,500 becoming refugees daily. The violence is ethnically motivated, targeting Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorian tribes, with reports of killing, rape, and targeting of civilians. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator in northern Uganda, Nasir Abel Fernandes, has called for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence, which he describes as a "massacre of civilians from both sides." Uganda, which has become a major refugee settlement, is struggling with the influx, with over a million refugees now residing in the country. Despite the challenges, the refugees, many of whom are children, are displaying resilience and maintaining their education and cultural

38-year-old boxer McKenzie, previously a footballer, turned professional in 2013. He has a record of 8 wins and 1 draw from 9 fights. He will face Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the £33m investment by the coalition for new NHS facilities in England, with £33m allocated for the construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped, leading to concerns about patient comfort and well-being. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for mobile scanners. In the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and work has begun on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, with the aim of completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was reportedly in or near a black Mercedes car when he was shot. The victim was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. The incident occurred during a family celebration, with relatives gathering for the event. There have been multiple shootings in Sheffield recently, but none have been close to the Upperthorpe area before this incident.

The passage discusses three main cyber warfare groups involved in the Ukraine conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their DDoS attacks, hacking into Russian servers, and monitoring CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. They have also been accused of providing data to Ukraine's security services for artillery fire targeting. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, hacks Ukrainian government websites, retrieves confidential documents, and disrupts electronic vote-counting systems. They also claim to have leaked Ukrainian defense ministry data and blocked President Poroshenko's website. Russian activist group Anonymous International focuses on Russia's domestic affairs and has published leaked documents from the Kremlin, including a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine and emails from a key rebel commander. Access to their website is currently blocked in Russia.

The passage discusses the farewell of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond from the Scottish Parliament. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governance. He also criticized the Scotland Bill, stating it did not fulfill the promises made during the referendum campaign. Salmond joked about the Cheltenham racecourse champion chase and wished everyone good luck in the upcoming election. He concluded with a heartfelt farewell.

Duncan McNeil, stepping down after serving since 1999, warned Holyrood about the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition, suggesting they should learn from Westminster's committee system. He also mentioned former Labour MP Robin Cook's visit to Holyrood for reform lessons.

Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell,

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She plans to gather experiences from older people, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations. The review will consider factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, Care Forum Wales has expressed disappointment that the commissioner did not include a provider expert on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company, reported a £800,000 increase in pre-tax profit to £3.5m in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m decrease in turnover to just over £100m. The company's international sales grew in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various sectors and operates 19 shops across Scotland under the Country Store brand. The company acknowledged the difficulty in predicting the agriculture outlook and the impact of Brexit, but expressed confidence in being well-positioned for business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. His 80-year-old companion was also taken to the hospital. The police are investigating the incident as a murder and are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. McLoughlin is described as a white man, about 6ft tall, with greying hair, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans, and a checked shirt. The police have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, warned of a weakening global economy in a speech, citing China's weaker-than-expected trade figures and a potential downgrade of the IMF's global growth forecast from 3.4% to reflect the current economic situation. This has significant implications for businesses and industries relying on China's growth story.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July due to the ongoing issues and to gather feedback. The ferry, a new vessel, has faced several problems since its launch on 14 May, including breaking down, running aground, and being suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. These problems have also caused damage to cars getting on and off the ferry. Local businesses, particularly those in East Cowes, have suffered significant losses due to the almost six months of trade disruption. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors and is considering compensation for local businesses. The transport councillor, Ian Ward, acknowledged the teething problems and mentioned that electrical issues have been resolved, and ramp extensions have been authorized to address vehicles scraping the concrete. Groundings were an issue with seamanship, which has been resolved as well.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was fatally injured at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, has been criticized for its job advertisements that prioritize physical appearance over skills and qualifications. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating that looks are important to their clients. However, the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have condemned the advertisements, calling them appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women. The EHRC has threatened to write to Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices immediately. The agency's advertisements for a personal assistant and a "sexy female driver" have been specifically criticized for their sexist and discriminatory language. Under the 2010 Equality Act, it is illegal to discriminate against anyone based on certain protected characteristics, including age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children, disability, race, or religion. Employers are also not allowed to question a candidate's clothing size unless it is essential to the nature or context of the work. Matching Models clients include MTV, Louis Vuit

The shooting incident occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, is accused of shooting 18-year-old Gautami in the head and injuring another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt. This incident is rare in India, where gun crimes at schools and colleges are uncommon. India has strict control laws, but firearms are still used to settle disputes. A similar incident occurred in Delhi in 2007, where a 14-year-old student was shot dead by two fellow students.

The passage highlights Glaad's analysis of LGBT representation in TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017. They found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with a significant increase in transgender characters from 7 to 16. However, the report also noted a concerning trend of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters meeting violent ends in shows like Orange is the New Black and Wentworth. Despite this, there was a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president expressed optimism about the progress made, but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the whole story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his resignation following allegations of mismanagement of public funds loaned to Northampton Town FC. Despite denying wrongdoing, he faced criticism for the loan from the borough council during his tenure as leader, with £10.25m missing and a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half-built. A majority of his party's local executive council had previously expressed support for deselecting him, but he announced his resignation despite initial plans to stand for re-election.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was fired for policy violations after fatally shooting Jordan Edwards, a 15-year-old boy, in the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs in April. The shooting occurred during a response to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers as they left the party, despite initial claims that the car was reversing towards the officer. He has been charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. If convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. He is currently free on bail.

The president-elect, Donald Trump, has announced that his wife, Melania Trump, and their son, Barron, will move to the White House "very soon, after he's finished with school." However, there is no specific date set. The announcement has sparked mixed reactions, with some praising Melania's decision and others criticizing it. Melania's decision to move her family to the White House is not unprecedented, as there have been two other First Ladies who also lived in the White House without their husbands: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. However, Melania's decision has its supporters, who argue that it is a responsible choice for a mother to stay at home with her child during her husband's presidency. The first lady's role is typically ceremonial, but some first ladies, such as Michelle Obama, have used their time in the White House to support and promote causes they care about. Melania has indicated that she will prioritize her role as First Lady over her other responsibilities, and she has expressed interest

A 72-year-old man died at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been appointed to examine the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaits the findings. A report on Pirc's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

The passage discusses a yellow warning of wind issued by the authorities, warning of gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) in the west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction potentially enhancing the impact. This is expected to cause disruption to travel on roads and at sea in the affected counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight, gusts brought down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road and expected to remain closed until Monday for clean-up work.

The Giants started with a short-handed goal by Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal, making it 2-1, and Andy Bohmback equalized. Mike Radja scored from a tight angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2. Nottingham's David Ling scored to make it 4-3. The teams play again on Saturday in a double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27, and Belfast with 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix saw Lewis Hamilton start from the back due to a broken front wing, suffering five pit stops. He faces a significant challenge in trying to overcome a 36-point deficit to championship leader Nico Rosberg. Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari came second, despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen's rise through the field, including passing Hamilton in the final stages, was aided by Ferrari's decision to use soft tyres. Hamilton expressed confidence in eroding Rosberg's points lead but acknowledged that no first-race winner has ever failed to claim the World Championship. The race was marked by incidents, including a collision between Hamilton and Nasr, and a puncture for Daniel Ricciardo due to debris from the first-lap chaos. Vettel confronted Kvyat about a potential collision, while Kvyat defended his actions. Ricciardo's puncture allowed Rosberg to take the lead and maintain his advantage. Mercedes stopped

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit. His announcement was met with support from various figures in German football, including his former teammates Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as leading figures in German football administration such as Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. The watershed moment is seen as a significant step in Germany's fight against homophobia, which has struggled with the issue like England. Previously, current Germany captain Philipp Lahm had expressed concerns about gay footballers coming out due to potential backlash. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman praised Hitzlsperger for his courage, and openly gay German politician Volker Beck hoped his announcement would encourage others to do the same. Zwanziger expressed optimism that Hitzlsperger's announcement would lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Brighton midfielder, Sidwell, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, contributing to the Seagulls' promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. His contract expires at the end of the season, and he hopes to sign a new deal. Sidwell, who has previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, made 19 appearances for Albion on loan from Stoke in the 2015-16 season. He believes he deserves another opportunity to play at the top level. Brighton is currently four points clear of second-placed Newcastle, aiming to secure the league title in the final two matches.

Blackpool took an early lead in the match against Colchester United, with Nathan Delfouneso scoring from a pinpoint chip into the area. However, Colchester equalized just before halftime through a corner kick, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from close range. Blackpool had a chance to regain the lead but failed to convert, while Colchester had a chance to take the lead but was denied by Sam Slocombe's brilliant save. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with both teams finishing with 10 men due to red cards and yellow cards.

29-year-old player made 37 appearances for Colchester United last season, who were relegated from League One. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He could make his debut for Colchester United in their EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester started their season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington Stanley.

The passage discusses the proposal for a permanent memorial to honor and commemorate the officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m to construct the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, containing the names of fallen officers, which will be given to their families as a personal memorial. The Home Secretary has pledged £1m towards the £4m needed for the project. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United, led by Sir Alex Ferguson, are 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left. They won 1-0 against Sunderland, extending their winning streak to 25 matches in the first 30 games. Ferguson emphasized the focus on the next game against Manchester City, with a 15-point lead. He also mentioned potential changes due to injuries, including Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, and the possibility of starting Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez. Ferguson praised Sunderland for making the game difficult but acknowledged Manchester United's determined defending and courage in securing the win.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK from 2006 to 2011, amounting to £10m. Google's CEO, Eric Schmidt, asserts that the company pays what is "legally required" and criticizes the UK government for its tax system. He suggests that taxes are not optional and that companies should pay as per the law. Schmidt proposes that if the UK changes its tax laws, Google will comply accordingly. The Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee's head, Margaret Hodge, suggests establishing a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, with the power to hear evidence from companies in secret. Google, known for routing UK sales through Ireland, is criticized for minimizing UK tax payments. European Union leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Schmidt advocates for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are taken, and calls for international tax reform and a debate on the rules.

NHS Improvement, the regulator, aims to reduce the £3.6bn spent on agency staff to £2.6bn by the end of the financial year. A £600m cap has been introduced since October, saving £600m. The cap limits agency staff costs to 55% above normal shift rates, with senior managers exempted. NHS trusts are 10% behind schedule, and while the agency bill is decreasing, it's unclear if other pay bills have increased. NHS Improvement will publish "league tables" of trusts' agency spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff. Concerns have been raised about hospitals being quoted double the rates for agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once a hub of commerce, has become a symbol of the end of the Celtic Tiger and Ireland's economic crash. Local traders like Matt O'Brien, who runs a men's clothing shop, have seen a 30% decrease in business but have recently noticed an improvement. The Fianna FÃ¡il opposition criticizes the government's half-a-billion euro investment in water meters, arguing it should be spent on broadband improvement. The Industrial Development Authority (IDA) has not brought any foreign direct investment to Longford in over four years. The government announces a 200m euro Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, which still needs planning permission. Traders believe more could be done to boost local business, such as free parking, which is a concern for residents.

The Cricket World Cup 2019 will conclude on 29th May in the same stadium. Eight teams will compete, playing each other twice. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. The fixtures and results are provided by BBC Sport. Four current or former England players will participate: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The tournament will follow a round-robin format, with each team playing every other team twice. The top two teams from the group stage will advance to the play-offs, which include Qualifier 1, Eliminator, and Qualifier 2, followed by the Final.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. These bags, often non-recyclable, are frequently discarded after use, accumulating in landfills and water bodies, posing significant environmental issues. To mitigate this, a 5p charge for plastic bags in England, effective from October, aims to promote reusage of existing bags. This strategy has been successful in reducing bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges are in place. Environmental campaigners hope this measure will also decrease plastic bag usage in England, thereby reducing environmental harm.

On Friday, December 23, a part of a school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, Wales, while hundreds of homes experienced power cuts due to the same weather event. The day was marked by train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts. This was due to a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales, which was in force until midnight on Friday. The highest gusts were recorded in Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and possible delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to expected high winds. The A55 Britannia Bridge in north Wales and the M48 Severn Bridge in Monmouthshire had earlier restrictions lifted, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in the sea in Denbighshire.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to reunite with Ryan Coogler for a new film, after their successful collaboration on Creed. He will also be working with Lupita Nyong'o, who won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The film is expected to be released in February 2018.

The passage discusses the restoration project of Alexandra Palace, which includes a theatre and BBC studios. The theatre, established in 1875, will host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018, with the help of £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund and £6.8m from Haringey Council. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust will raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still has much of its original decor and stage machinery.

The passage provides information about a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who won 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. However, he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The player, who made his first appearance in 2004, recently expressed his wish for success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Marcy Smith and her daughter were awakened by their son David to find their Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador home engulfed in flames. The family escaped but their dog and cats did not. The fire started from rubbish burned in the wood stove and the fire alarm did not go off. David, who was on FaceTime with his father, saw the flames and they managed to escape just seconds before the entire kitchen disappeared. The family had only pyjamas on but the community rallied to donate clothes, shoes, and even a bike for David. Marcy Smith is grateful for her son's quick thinking and the community's support.

The passage suggests that the owners of West Ham United, David Sullivan and Gary Gold, who bought a majority stake in 2010, are considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club. They currently own over 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but they intend to pass on the ownership to their children.

The 2014 People's Choice Awards, held in Los Angeles, was a ceremony that celebrated both fan-voted awards and an unofficial promotional platform for summer's blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won the most awards, including best movie, best female performance for Shailene Woodley, and best kiss scene with Ansel Elgort. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street. Meryl Streep received best villain for Into the Woods. Kevin Hart, despite size-related jokes, accepted the comedic genius award with his kids. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award with clips from Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron shown.

Aberdeen loaned 21-year-old forward Cammy Smith to St Mirren in July. Smith has scored five goals for St Mirren this season and has a total of four goals in 89 appearances for Aberdeen. Manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a "brilliant acquisition" and a "good, mature boy" who will provide another attacking option for St Mirren. St Mirren will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council plans to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months using its Jetpatcher machines, which can now operate in warmer weather. Additionally, the council will repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters due to heavy rain.

The incident involved six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland last December. They were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing a piece of pipework. The exposure level was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). EnQuest advised the HSE of the matter at the time and has appropriate control measures in place to prevent such exposure. Following an investigation, additional precautionary steps have been taken. The workers have been undergoing medical assessments and continue to face cancer fears. They claim EnQuest failed in its duty of care and that they were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE). The union representative, John Boland, criticized the lack of openness and transparency regarding the incident. The HSE has been made aware of the incident but no investigation has been carried out as it was not reportable under the present RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. In 2012, the dealer's manager admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze. The ASI requested the sculpture's return, and after discussions with the National Heritage Board and the ASI, ACM decided to return the item. The museum will seek compensation for the alleged fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. It was felt in Milan, Florence, and other cities, causing several aftershocks and power cuts. The epicenter was in Garfagnana, where phone lines were down and schools were evacuated. Last May, a magnitude-6 earthquake in the same area killed more than 20 people. The latest quake was described as a classic, medium-strong earthquake for the area. Italy is still recovering from the L'Aquila earthquake, where six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter for providing false reassurances about a deadly quake in 2009.

8 September 2016: Austin Grant from Sheffield was skeptical about South Yorkshire's climate suitability for growing fruit. However, he was thrilled to see results, with a fruit still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption.

Rockstar Games has delayed the release of their open-world adventure game, Grand Theft Auto V, from 27 January to 24 March. The delay is due to additional testing and polishing to ensure the best possible experience. However, the company announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. Screenshots of the PC version have been released, showcasing greater detail and improved graphics. The minimum specifications for running the game have also been revealed. GTA V, which became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generated $1bn in revenue in just three days after its release on 17 September 2013.

The 76-year-old artist, Simpson, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. He has won the prize three times before and was shortlisted in 1991. The judge, Ansel Krut, praised the painting as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem". Simpson's painting depicts a leper squint, a hole made in medieval churches for undesirables to look at the service. He entered it into the competition due to its small size and his familiarity with it. The prize money will be spent on materials, particularly good quality paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, the current patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Four masked assailants attacked the offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit in Istanbul on Thursday morning, causing significant damage and shattering windows with gunfire. No casualties were reported, but numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, with the Yeni Safak building being 20km away from the Yeni Akit offices. The police are currently investigating the incidents, as no group has claimed responsibility yet. This is not the first time pro-government protesters have targeted the offices of a opposition newspaper, as pro-government protesters attacked the offices of Hurriyet last September, accusing the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

24-year-old player, previously on loan at Crawley with 3 goals in 23 appearances, will join Scunthorpe United on a free transfer from Stags on 1st January. This is Marcus Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

The passage discusses the potential appointment of Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger as the new England manager, following the current manager Gareth Southgate's successful qualification for the World Cup and his upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger has been linked with the job but maintains that he focuses on his current role. He emphasizes the importance of a manager's competency over their name, stating that Southgate has a good opportunity to prove himself. Wenger also mentions that Arsenal right-back Hector Bellerin, who has been linked with a move to Barcelona and Manchester City, will be offered a new contract. Wenger is "surprised" by the speculation surrounding Bellerin, who progressed through Barcelona's La Masia academy before joining Arsenal in 2011. Wenger also confirms that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are investigating the incident, with the company fully cooperating.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, Hellier and Hildasay. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The contracted out services will return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. Seatruck, which operates the vessels, argued the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements will come into force early next month, subject to financial and regulatory details being finalized. The Minister confirmed that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage going forward. Serco Northlink operates three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a heavily subsidized route by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother. Mitchell was visibly shaking after the verdict, which found him guilty of common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice. Mitchell and his mother, Samantha, had initially lied about the incident but later admitted Mitchell had tried to push the couple apart, causing an accident. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, passed away in London at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He was known as "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile. Temperton's songwriting was influenced by his father's habit of putting a transistor radio in his crib. He started his career in the 1970s, working as a keyboardist for disco group Heatwave and later writing songs for Michael Jackson's Off The Wall and Thriller albums. His tunes have also been recorded by artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. He is survived by his family, who requested privacy during this "saddest of sad times."

Swansea University researchers have discovered ancient earthworks in the Brazilian Amazon, possibly 2,000 years old. The team, including researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading, and SÃ£o Paulo, found over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" hidden by rainforest until recent deforestation. The function of these sites is still unknown, but they are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures. They may have been used as ritual gathering places, similar to Stonehenge. The team used soil samples and microscopic plant fossils to reconstruct ancient vegetation and found that the geoglyphs were likely constructed among taller vegetation, suggesting they were not visible above the forest canopy. This challenges the assumption that the Amazonian forests were pristine before European contact. The research indicates a variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans, suggesting a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. The team found "tantalizing evidence" that some

21-year-old Australian tennis player, Nick Kyrgios, defeated world number 29, Mike Berrett, 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won the Japan Open on Sunday and is close to the top 10. However, he admitted to feeling tired and bored, which may have contributed to his quieter demeanor compared to his usual self. The travel and playing conditions in Japan, including a long ride to the courts, are believed to have affected his performance. This is not the first time Kyrgios has had issues with the travel and conditions at the Shanghai Masters, as he was fined $1,500 (£984) for a foul-mouthed outburst at the tournament last year.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of expanding the HPV vaccination program in Wales to include boys, as the virus is sexually transmitted and can cause head and neck cancers. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. Charities and organizations are calling for the vaccination to be rolled out to boys due to the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunization before making a decision. The HPV virus causes 5% of the global cancer burden, and expanding the vaccination program could help stem the tide of these cancers.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Calder High School, passed away after a battle with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He had been documenting his journey on social media since his diagnosis in August. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was an avid Rangers fan. He attended his prom briefly before being hospitalized and received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Jak's family set up a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in his memory. A special football match is being held to raise more funds for charity.

Egypt won the match 1-0 against Uganda, with the winning goal scored by Mohamed Salah in the 89th minute, assisted by Abdallah El Said. The match was played in Port-Gentil, with Egypt playing with a resolute defense against Uganda's offensive play. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside, and Egypt had several chances to score but failed to convert. The win means Egypt plays Ghana in the last round of group games for top spot, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College, is also unused. The decision comes after a study by Network Rail, which found that Skelmersdale could get two direct trains to Liverpool per hour under the council's plans. The council, which owns Glenburn Sports College, aims to improve connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale was designated a new town in 1961 and is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.

The passage mentions that plants were discovered during a search of a warehouse in Ashbourne on Saturday morning. These plants were found in an "elaborate grow house". A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, has been arrested and is in custody. The motive for the attack is not yet clear. The woman was taken to a specialist clinic after undergoing an emergency operation. Police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, Warwick, and Wisconsin universities found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. This contradicts the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for more money. The study compared full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females, eliminating any impact from part-time workers earning less. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The research also found no evidence for the idea that women are reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a stereotype. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, which is thought to be the only country to systematically record whether employees had asked for a pay rise and why they had or had not done so. The findings suggest there is some element of pure discrimination against women. The study also found differences

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but all council-owned sites have been deemed unsuitable due to factors such as site size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. The council has not given up and is still exploring options, with the only alternatives being the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes after the cemeteries are full. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, is offering an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to access online information from site signs and posters, view videos and band interviews on phones and tablets. The festival features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The director, Caroline Maclennan, stated that this feature will enhance the festival experience for local visitors and provide global interaction, allowing people to access information, interviews, tickets, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated leading up to the festival and during the event.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, and there were no significant underlying health issues. The horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, this was the first time he collapsed. The British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the cause of such incidents and prevent them.

The 15-year-old girl, who has learning difficulties, met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who later changed her name to Davina, is accused of raping the girl while two others were asleep. The girl recalled the incident, having only consumed a can and a half of Foster's beer. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire. The girl attempted suicide last summer, and Ayrton will be sentenced on 4 March, to be held at a male prison in Winchester due to safety concerns. Protocols have been set for her detention, and she has not undergone any physical changes or taken medication related to her sexuality.

The Serbs, consisting of Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares, defeated world number one Novak Djokovic and Juan Martin del Potro 6-4, 6-4 in the Rio Olympics. This loss came a day after Djokovic was eliminated in the singles round by del Potro. Djokovic, a 12-time Grand Slam champion, had previously won the Toronto Masters title before the Olympics.

20+ competitors will participate in Saturday's carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. Contestants include carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US. They must use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh player, has not played since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is close to a return and is undergoing a pre-season training phase. He aims to take each week as it comes and is hopeful of returning to the field at the beginning of February, with a possible extension of a couple of weeks. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign against Ireland in Dublin on 7 February. Webb, who has been capped 16 times for Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. He turned down offers from other teams to stay at his home region, where he made his debut in 2007.

Two men were arrested near the US-Canada border in Washington state for attempting to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody immediately, while the other, Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their alleged involvement in the smuggling operation. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The incident occurred in a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 counseling sessions in the past year compared to around 2,400 in 2011-12. The true extent of online bullying is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have been affected, experiencing torment, abuse, and fear of attending school. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children from bullying, which can worsen without intervention. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, to raise awareness and combat the problem. A young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being targeted online and the emotional distress it caused. They advised other young people to seek help and stand up for themselves when dealing with bullying.

The Israeli government, led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is considering postponing a vote on authorizing new housing units in the settlement of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot in East Jerusalem, following a US decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction. The resolution, which passed with 14 votes in favor, is considered a blow to Israel as it views East Jerusalem as part of its capital, while the Palestinians want it as the capital of their future state. The US accused Israel of helping draft the resolution and pushing for its passage, which Israel denies. Israel has also recalled its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister in response to the resolution. US Secretary of State John Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict later on Wednesday.

The passage is about Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, which was celebrated with various events and tributes. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, met staff and viewed an exhibition at Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office. She also officially opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and met pupils from the six schools involved in its decoration. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn wished her a happy birthday at Prime Minister's Questions. Prince William spoke about his mother's duty, service, tolerance, and commitment to others, which have been a guiding example for him. He also addressed the recent headlines about him being a "work-shy" prince, stating that he accepts criticism but doesn't let it influence his decisions. The Queen will light a beacon in the evening to mark the milestone birthday, and US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle. The passage also mentions ten stamps

Cheltenham Town lost 2-0 to West Ham United in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham, while Cheltenham had few chances. The match took place at West Ham's Upton Park, where they won the previous meeting four years ago. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died after a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, was found guilty of causing death by careless driving. He pleaded guilty at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. Werner's family, who were staying in a cottage near Bala, saw no value in him being sent to jail as they accepted it was a momentary lapse. Werner was remorseful but had no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British man from Southall, west London, is accused of being one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from the Syria conflict. He, under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group of British fighters affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was known for his online presence, posting videos and pictures of his personal jihad in Syria. He was involved in fundraising, propaganda, and appeals for donations. However, he faked his own death and tried to slip back into the UK unnoticed, leading to his arrest and prosecution at the Old Bailey. Khawaja is currently facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in the conflict.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish 8th in the table. Barnsley has signed him as their third player for the upcoming League One play-off final at Wembley. The caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and defensive skills, stating that he will fit well with the team's playing style. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season.

Volunteers are clearing bottles from Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, believed to be from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End. The bottles, sealed but some leaking, pose a risk to wildlife. Other coves are also affected, causing concern for marine life. The National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation, with the bottles being cleared away by the trust. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from any more washed-up bottles.

A car crash happened on the A9 near Berriedale, Caithness, at 14:00, injuring several people. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 to Melvich. Police are investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Wanderers, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and securing promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite's contribution was particularly significant towards the end of the campaign. He has since signed a new contract with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage describes a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour over their cooperation on Brexit-related issues. The Lib Dems, led by Lord Oates, accused Labour of being willing to concede on issues like EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, Labour, led by Baroness Smith, argued that the Lib Dems were giving people false hope. The two parties had previously worked together to defeat the government on these issues, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected the amendments. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for "grandstanding" and building false hope, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with the Conservatives on Brexit. The passage also mentions that the two parties have a history of forming alliances to impose government defeats on various bills. Despite this, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and doubted the likelihood of a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering,

The election issue of foreign policy and the role of UK's defence forces at home and abroad includes defence spending and the UK's military capabilities. The Conservative and Labour parties have made significant cuts to their armed forces, reducing the size of the regular Army, the Royal Navy's fleet, and the RAF's front-line fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen behind other nations in defence spending, with only two parties committed to meeting the 2% GDP target. The MoD has reason to be nervous as further cuts could lead to significant savings in defence, potentially impacting the UK's credibility as a key ally. The Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent, while Labour, the Liberal Democrats, the SNP, and the Greens have different views on nuclear deterrence and CASD. The Royal Navy's two new aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth and the Prince of Wales, face challenges in crewing and equipping them with the F-3

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with additional fees totaling £106.8m, including a £34m payment to Neymar's parents. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated. A judge in Spain has ruled to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona has made a £13.55m tax declaration to defend their reputation, but they maintain the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored 15 goals in total for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, a 66-year-old man who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family and Age UK have called for retired drivers to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations. Newman's car was heading north on the southbound carriageway when it collided with a van Luciw was traveling in. Luciw's colleague, Andy Harrington, was also in the van and survived with serious injuries. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The passage discusses the safety concerns of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in Scotland. Two original review group members resigned due to a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report, which concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and informed choices, and that reporting of adverse events be mandatory. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the power to ban the procedures, as that lies with the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, who had suffered complications from the surgery, resigned from the review group earlier this year. A consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh

Muir, a 23-year-old, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record for 5000 meters by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan, who had raised concerns about the criteria for record-breaking attempts, acknowledged Muir's achievement. She had earlier expressed doubts about whether Muir's race met the requirements, as it was a mixed 3K race where only Muir finished the 5K. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's ability and potential to win world medals, noting that her time was similar to McColgan's own record-breaking race 25 years ago. Muir had previously broken her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

In the 2016 Rio Olympics equestrian event, Jung won the gold medal aboard Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who contracted an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and America's Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt, 47, competed despite being placed in an induced coma 10 months prior, but his medal bid was ruined by a poor cross-country performance. He finished 12th after leading after dressage but incurring time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished 9th on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

30-year-old British tennis player Andy Murray won his fourth round match at Wimbledon against Italian 29th seed Fognini. Murray won 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to seal the victory. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray was not at his best but managed to get through the match. The match was tense and Murray avoided a long, drawn-out contest in the third set. On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death. Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched their manifesto, 'Real Partnership', which includes plans to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and ensure no group is worse off due to Brexit. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, announced that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales in implementing automatic pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences. This includes posthumous pardons for those who have passed away and the option for living men to apply for a pardon. The law, known as 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing and aims to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, who have historically faced different treatment compared to their counterparts in England and Wales. The minister has secured executive agreement to introduce a legislative consent motion for the pardon of convictions related to abolished sexual offences, with the aim of addressing past wrongs and providing earlier resolution than an assembly bill. 23-year-old Scottish runner Laura Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m event, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12. This result improved upon Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60. Muir also holds the Scottish records for the 1500m and mile events. She is currently preparing for the British trials in Birmingham on June 24-26 to secure an Olympics spot for Great Britain in Rio. Steve Smith, at 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, following Michael Clarke's retirement. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests last summer. He has played in 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights, stating that he is "passionate" about them and will prioritize equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people. In 2015, Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in the UK, leading to the loss of 450 jobs. However, Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical firm, has since taken over the plant to produce its pharmaceuticals. Accord aims to fill many of the jobs with former Sanofi staff and is confident the investment will have a positive impact on the local economy. Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance, and heads of the chief executive's office (Ciaran Monaghan) and human resources and customer services (Ewan Sutherland), are all leaving the local authority. The English rider, Martin, has decided to stop road racing on Hondas this year after crashing at the TT and facing mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube following Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version. Tunisia was facing expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against CAF, but was allowed to participate after apologizing. England won the match against Pakistan with a significant margin at Old Trafford, leveling the series. 36-year-old former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but decided it was too soon. He is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

Morton won the match 3-1 against Alloa Athletic. McManus scored twice, with Forbes' deflected strike doubling the lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa in the first half. McManus and Johnstone scored in the second half to secure the victory for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham. Anyone running illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed shock at the conditions found. It is understood that 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, which will apply to all religious groups operating in unsafe accommodation. Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is Scotland's first new distillery in nearly 200 years. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, the gin production is unique due to its small still and compact operation, fitting into a cowshed. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery and is set to use local sourcing, aligning with its ethos. The gin's name, Lilliard, is derived from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, near the distillery site.

Harry Whitlam, 22, was fatally injured in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, driving a tractor on private land, reversed into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's grief and hoped that Harry's life would be remembered for the good times they shared.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches after appealing against a four-month ban from football. Suarez can now attend matches, take part in promotional activities, and will likely make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October.
